with who we are as people.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Here's another one -- completely different one:

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Why is it

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that we don't do the blindingly obvious things we should do

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
to combat climate change,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
very, very simple things

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
like buying energy-efficient appliances,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
putting in efficient lights, turning the lights off occasionally,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
insulating our homes?

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
These things save carbon, they save energy,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
they save us money.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
So is it that, though they make perfect economic sense,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
we don't do them?

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Well, I had my own personal insight into this

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
a few years ago.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
It was a Sunday evening, Sunday afternoon,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
and it was just after --

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
actually, to be honest, too long after --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
we had moved into a new house.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And I had finally got around to doing some draft stripping,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
installing insulation around the windows and doors

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
to keep out the drafts.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And my, then, five year-old daughter

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
was helping me in the way that five year-olds do.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And we'd been doing this for a while,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
when she turned to me very solemnly and said,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
"Will this really keep out the giraffes?"

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
(Laughter)

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
"Here they are, the giraffes."

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
You can hear the five-year-old mind working.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
These ones, interestingly, are 400 miles north of here

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
outside Barrow-in-Furness in Cumbria.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Goodness knows what they make of the Lake District weather.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
But actually that childish misrepresentation

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
stuck with me,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
because it suddenly became clear to me

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
why we don't do the blindingly obvious things.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
We're too busy keeping out the giraffes --

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
putting the kids on the bus in the morning,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
getting ourselves to work on time,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
surviving email overload

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and shop floor politics,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
foraging for groceries, throwing together meals,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
escaping for a couple of precious hours in the evening

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
into prime-time TV

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
or TED online,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
getting from one end of the day to the other,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
keeping out the giraffes.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
(Laughter)

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
What is the objective?

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
"What is the objective of the consumer?"

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Mary Douglas asked in an essay on poverty

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
written 35 years ago.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
"It is," she said,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
"to help create the social world

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and find a credible place in it."

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
That is a deeply humanizing

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
vision of our lives,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and it's a completely different vision

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
than the one that lies at the heart

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
of this economic model.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
So who are we?

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
Who are these people?

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Are we these novelty-seeking, hedonistic,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
selfish individuals?

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Or might we actually occasionally be

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
something like the selfless altruist

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
depicted in Rembrandt's lovely, lovely sketch here?

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Well psychology actually says

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
there is a tension --

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
a tension between self-regarding behaviors

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and other regarding behaviors.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And these tensions have deep evolutionary roots,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
so selfish behavior

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
is adaptive in certain circumstances --

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
fight or flight.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
But other regarding behaviors

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
are essential to our evolution

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
as social beings.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And perhaps even more interesting from our point of view,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
another tension between novelty-seeking behaviors

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and tradition or conservation.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
Novelty is adaptive when things are changing

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and you need to adapt yourself.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Tradition is essential to lay down the stability

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
to raise families and form cohesive social groups.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
So here, all of a sudden,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
we're looking at a map of the human heart.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And it reveals to us, suddenly,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
the crux of the matter.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
What we've done is we've created economies.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
We've created systems,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
which systematically privilege, encourage,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
one narrow quadrant

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
of the human soul

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and left the others unregarded.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And in the same token, the solution becomes clear,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
because this isn't, therefore,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
about changing human nature.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
It isn't, in fact, about curtailing possibilities.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
It is about opening up.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
It is about allowing ourselves the freedom

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
to become fully human,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
recognizing the depth and the breadth

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
of the human psyche

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and building institutions

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
to protect Rembrandt's fragile altruist within.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
What does all this mean for economics?

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
What would economies look like

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
if we took that vision of human nature

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
at their heart

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and stretched them

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
along these orthogonal dimensions

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
of the human psyche?

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Well, it might look a little bit

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
like the 4,000 community-interest companies

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
that have sprung up in the U.K. over the last five years

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
and a similar rise in B corporations in the United States,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
enterprises

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
that have ecological and social goals

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
written into their constitution

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
at their heart --

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
companies, in fact, like this one, Ecosia.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
And I just want to, very quickly, show you this.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
Ecosia is an Internet search engine.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Internet search engines work

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
by drawing revenues from sponsored links

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
that appear when you do a search.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
And Ecosia works in pretty much the same way.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So we can do that here --

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
we can just put in a little search term.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
There you go, Oxford, that's where we are. See what comes up.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
The difference with Ecosia though

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
is that, in Ecosia's case,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
it draws the revenues in the same way,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
but it allocates

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
80 percent of those revenues

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
to a rainforest protection project in the Amazon.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And we're going to do it.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
We're just going to click on Naturejobs.uk.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
In case anyone out there is looking for a job in a recession,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
that's the page to go to.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And what happened then was

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
the sponsor gave revenues to Ecosia,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and Ecosia is giving 80 percent of those revenues

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
to a rainforest protection project.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
It's taking profits from one place

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and allocating them

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
into the protection of ecological resources.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
It's a different kind of enterprise

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
for a new economy.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
It's a form, if you like,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
of ecological altruism --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
perhaps something along those lines. Maybe it's that.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Whatever it is,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
whatever this new economy is,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
what we need the economy to do, in fact,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
is to put investment

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
back into the heart of the model,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
to re-conceive investment.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
Only now, investment

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
isn't going to be

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
about the relentless and mindless

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
pursuit of consumption growth.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Investment has to be a different beast.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Investment has to be,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
in the new economy,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
protecting and nurturing

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
the ecological assets on which our future depends.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
It has to be about transition.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
It has to be investing in low-carbon technologies

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and infrastructures.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
We have to invest, in fact,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
in the idea of a meaningful prosperity,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
providing capabilities

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
for people to flourish.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And of course, this task has material dimensions.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
It would be nonsense to talk about people flourishing

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
if they didn't have food, clothing and shelter.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
But it's also clear that prosperity goes beyond this.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
It has social and psychological aims --

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
family, friendship,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
commitments, society,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
participating in the life of that society.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And this too

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
requires investment,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
investment -- for example, in places --

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
places where we can connect,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
places where we can participate,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
shared spaces,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
concert halls, gardens,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
public parks,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
libraries, museums, quiet centers,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
places of joy and celebration,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
places of tranquility and contemplation,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
sites for the "cultivation

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
of a common citizenship,"

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
in Michael Sandel's lovely phrase.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
An investment -- investment, after all, is just such a basic economic concept --

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
is nothing more nor less

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
than a relationship

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
between the present and the future,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
a shared present and a common future.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
And we need that relationship to reflect,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
to reclaim hope.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
So let me come back, with this sense of hope,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
to the two billion people

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
still trying to live each day

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
on less than the price of a skinny latte

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
from the cafe next door.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
What can we offer those people?

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
It's clear that we have a responsibility

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
to help lift them out of poverty.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
It's clear that we have a responsibility

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
to make room for growth

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
where growth really matters in those poorest nations.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And it's also clear that we will never achieve that

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
unless we're capable of redefining

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
a meaningful sense of prosperity in the richer nations,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
a prosperity that is more meaningful

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
and less materialistic

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
than the growth-based model.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
So this is not just

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
a Western post-materialist fantasy.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
In fact, an African philosopher wrote to me,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
when "Prosperity Without Growth" was published,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
pointing out the similarities

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
between this view of prosperity

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
and the traditional African concept of ubuntu.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
Ubuntu says, "I am

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
because we are."

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Prosperity is a shared endeavor.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Its roots are long and deep --

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
its foundations, I've tried to show,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
exist already, inside each of us.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
So this is not about

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
standing in the way of development.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
It's not about

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
overthrowing capitalism.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
It's not about

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
trying to change human nature.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
What we're doing here

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
is we're taking a few simple steps

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
towards an economics fit for purpose.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
And at the heart of that economics,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
we're placing a more credible,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
more robust,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
and more realistic vision

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
of what it means to be human.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:06.958
(Applause)

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
Chris Anderson: While they're taking the podium away, just a quick question.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
First of all, economists aren't supposed to be inspiring,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
so you may need to work on the tone a little.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
(Laughter)

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
Can you picture the politicians ever buying into this?

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
I mean, can you picture

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
a politician standing up in Britain and saying,

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
"GDP fell two percent this year. Good news!

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
We're actually all happier, and a country's more beautiful,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and our lives are better."

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
Tim Jackson: Well that's clearly not what you're doing.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
You're not making news out of things falling down.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
You're making news out of the things that tell you that we're flourishing.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
Can I picture politicians doing it?

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
Actually, I already am seeing a little bit of it.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
When we first started this kind of work,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:46.958
politicians would stand up, treasury spokesmen would stand up,

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:49.958
and accuse us of wanting to go back and live in caves.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
And actually in the period

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
through which we've been working over the last 18 years --

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
partly because of the financial crisis

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
and a little bit of humility in the profession of economics --

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
actually people are engaging in this issue

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
in all sorts of countries around the world.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
CA: But is it mainly politicians who are going to have to get their act together,

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
or is it going to be more just civil society and companies?

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
TJ: It has to be companies. It has to be civil society.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
But it has to have political leadership.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
This is a kind of agenda,

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
which actually politicians themselves

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
are kind of caught in that dilemma,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
because they're hooked on the growth model themselves.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
But actually opening up the space

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
to think about different ways of governing,

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
different kinds of politics,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
and creating the space

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
for civil society and businesses to operate differently --

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
absolutely vital.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
CA: And if someone could convince you

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
that we actually can make the -- what was it? --

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
the 130-fold improvement in efficiency,

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
of reduction of carbon footprint,

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
would you then actually like that picture of economic growth

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
into more knowledge-based goods?

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
TJ: I would still want to know that you could do that

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
and get below zero by the end of the century,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
in terms of taking carbon out of the atmosphere,

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
and solve the problem of biodiversity

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
and reduce the impact on land use

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
and do something about the erosion of topsoils and the quality of water.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
If you can convince me we can do all that,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:06.958
then, yes, I would take the two percent.

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
CA: Tim, thank you for a very important talk. Thank you.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
(Applause)

title: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean
transcript: I've been fascinated for a lifetime by the beauty, form and function of giant bluefin tuna. Bluefin are warmblooded like us. They're the largest of the tunas, the second-largest fish in the sea — bony fish. They actually are a fish that is endothermic — powers through the ocean with warm muscles like a mammal. That's one of our bluefin at the Monterey Bay Aquarium. You can see in its shape and its streamlined design it's powered for ocean swimming. It flies through the ocean on its pectoral fins, gets lift, powers its movements with a lunate tail. It's actually got a naked skin for most of its body, so it reduces friction with the water. This is what one of nature's finest machines.Now, bluefin were revered by Man for all of human history. For 4,000 years, we fished sustainably for this animal, and it's evidenced in the art that we see from thousands of years ago. Bluefin are in cave paintings in France. They're on coins that date back 3,000 years. This fish was revered by humankind. It was fished sustainably till all of time, except for our generation. Bluefin are pursued wherever they go — there is a gold rush on Earth, and this is a gold rush for bluefin. There are traps that fish sustainably up until recently. And yet, the type of fishing going on today, with pens, with enormous stakes, is really wiping bluefin ecologically off the planet. Now bluefin, in general, goes to one place: Japan. Some of you may be guilty of having contributed to the demise of bluefin. They're delectable muscle, rich in fat — absolutely taste delicious. And that's their problem; we're eating them to death. Now in the Atlantic, the story is pretty simple. Bluefin have two populations: one large, one small. The North American population is fished at about 2,000 ton. The European population and North African — the Eastern bluefin tuna — is fished at tremendous levels: 50,000 tons over the last decade almost every year.The result is whether you're looking at the West or the Eastern bluefin population, there's been tremendous decline on both sides, as much as 90 percent if you go back with your baseline to 1950. For that, bluefin have been given a status equivalent to tigers, to lions, to certain African elephants and to pandas. These fish have been proposed for an endangered species listing in the past two months. They were voted on and rejected just two weeks ago, despite outstanding science that shows from two committees this fish meets the criteria of CITES I. And if it's tunas you don't care about, perhaps you might be interested that international long lines and pursing chase down tunas and bycatch animals such as leatherbacks, sharks, marlin, albatross. These animals and their demise occurs in the tuna fisheries. The challenge we face is that we know very little about tuna, and everyone in the room knows what it looks like when an African lion takes down its prey. I doubt anyone has seen a giant bluefin feed. This tuna symbolizes what's the problem for all of us in the room.It's the 21st century, but we really have only just begun to really study our oceans in a deep way. Technology has come of age that's allowing us to see the Earth from space and go deep into the seas remotely. And we've got to use these technologies immediately to get a better understanding of how our ocean realm works. Most of us from the ship — even I — look out at the ocean and see this homogeneous sea. We don't know where the structure is. We can't tell where are the watering holes like we can on an African plain. We can't see the corridors, and we can't see what it is that brings together a tuna, a leatherback and an albatross. We're only just beginning to understand how the physical oceanography and the biological oceanography come together to create a seasonal force that actually causes the upwelling that might make a hot spot a hope spot. The reasons these challenges are great is that technically it's difficult to go to sea. It's hard to study a bluefin on its turf, the entire Pacific realm. It's really tough to get up close and personal with a mako shark and try to put a tag on it. And then imagine being Bruce Mate's team from OSU, getting up close to a blue whale and fixing a tag on the blue whale that stays, an engineering challenge we've yet to really overcome.So the story of our team, a dedicated team, is fish and chips. We basically are taking the same satellite phone parts, or the same parts that are in your computer, chips. We're putting them together in unusual ways, and this is taking us into the ocean realm like never before. And for the first time, we're able to watch the journey of a tuna beneath the ocean using light and photons to measure sunrise and sunset. Now, I've been working with tunas for over 15 years. I have the privilege of being a partner with the Monterey Bay Aquarium. We've actually taken a sliver of the ocean, put it behind glass, and we together have put bluefin tuna and yellowfin tuna on display. When the veil of bubbles lifts every morning, we can actually see a community from the Pelagic ocean, one of the only places on Earth you can see giant bluefin swim by. We can see in their beauty of form and function, their ceaseless activity. They're flying through their space, ocean space. And we can bring two million people a year into contact with this fish and show them its beauty.Behind the scenes is a working lab at Stanford University partnered with the Monterey Bay Aquarium. Here, for over 14 or 15 years, we've actually brought in both bluefin and yellowfin in captivity. We'd been studying these fish, but first we had to learn how to husbandry them. What do they like to eat? What is it that they're happy with? We go in the tanks with the tuna — we touch their naked skin — it's pretty amazing. It feels wonderful. And then, better yet, we've got our own version of tuna whisperers, our own Chuck Farwell, Alex Norton, who can take a big tuna and in one motion, put it into an envelope of water, so that we can actually work with the tuna and learn the techniques it takes to not injure this fish who never sees a boundary in the open sea. Jeff and Jason there, are scientists who are going to take a tuna and put it in the equivalent of a treadmill, a flume. And that tuna thinks it's going to Japan, but it's staying in place. We're actually measuring its oxygen consumption, its energy consumption. We're taking this data and building better models. And when I see that tuna — this is my favorite view — I begin to wonder: how did this fish solve the longitude problem before we did? So take a look at that animal. That's the closest you'll probably ever get. Now, the activities from the lab have taught us now how to go out in the open ocean.So in a program called Tag-A-Giant we've actually gone from Ireland to Canada, from Corsica to Spain. We've fished with many nations around the world in an effort to basically put electronic computers inside giant tunas. We've actually tagged 1,100 tunas. And I'm going to show you three clips, because I tagged 1,100 tunas. It's a very hard process, but it's a ballet. We bring the tuna out, we measure it. A team of fishers, captains, scientists and technicians work together to keep this animal out of the ocean for about four to five minutes. We put water over its gills, give it oxygen. And then with a lot of effort, after tagging, putting in the computer, making sure the stalk is sticking out so it senses the environment, we send this fish back into the sea. And when it goes, we're always happy. We see a flick of the tail. And from our data that gets collected, when that tag comes back, because a fisher returns it for a thousand-dollar reward, we can get tracks beneath the sea for up to five years now, on a backboned animal.Now sometimes the tunas are really large, such as this fish off Nantucket. But that's about half the size of the biggest tuna we've ever tagged. It takes a human effort, a team effort, to bring the fish in. In this case, what we're going to do is put a pop-up satellite archival tag on the tuna. This tag rides on the tuna, senses the environment around the tuna and actually will come off the fish, detach, float to the surface and send back to Earth-orbiting satellites position data estimated by math on the tag, pressure data and temperature data. And so what we get then from the pop-up satellite tag is we get away from having to have a human interaction to recapture the tag. Both the electronic tags I'm talking about are expensive. These tags have been engineered by a variety of teams in North America. They are some of our finest instruments, our new technology in the ocean today. One community in general has given more to help us than any other community. And that's the fisheries off the state of North Carolina. There are two villages, Harris and Morehead City, every winter for over a decade, held a party called Tag-A-Giant, and together, fishers worked with us to tag 800 to 900 fish. In this case, we're actually going to measure the fish. We're going to do something that in recent years we've started: take a mucus sample. Watch how shiny the skin is; you can see my reflection there. And from that mucus, we can get gene profiles, we can get information on gender, checking the pop-up tag one more time, and then it's out in the ocean. And this is my favorite.With the help of my former postdoc, Gareth Lawson, this is a gorgeous picture of a single tuna. This tuna is actually moving on a numerical ocean. The warm is the Gulf Stream, the cold up there in the Gulf of Maine. That's where the tuna wants to go — it wants to forage on schools of herring — but it can't get there. It's too cold. But then it warms up, and the tuna pops in, gets some fish, maybe comes back to home base, goes in again and then comes back to winter down there in North Carolina and then on to the Bahamas. And my favorite scene, three tunas going into the Gulf of Mexico. Three tunas tagged. Astronomically, we're calculating positions. They're coming together. That could be tuna sex — and there it is. That is where the tuna spawn. So from data like this, we're able now to put the map up, and in this map you see thousands of positions generated by this decade and a half of tagging. And now we're showing that tunas on the western side go to the eastern side. So two populations of tunas — that is, we have a Gulf population, one that we can tag — they go to the Gulf of Mexico, I showed you that — and a second population. Living amongst our tunas — our North American tunas — are European tunas that go back to the Med. On the hot spots — the hope spots — they're mixed populations.And so what we've done with the science is we're showing the International Commission, building new models, showing them that a two-stock no-mixing model — to this day, used to reject the CITES treaty — that model isn't the right model. This model, a model of overlap, is the way to move forward. So we can then predict where management places should be. Places like the Gulf of Mexico and the Mediterranean are places where the single species, the single population, can be captured. These become forthright in places we need to protect. The center of the Atlantic where the mixing is, I could imagine a policy that lets Canada and America fish, because they manage their fisheries well, they're doing a good job. But in the international realm, where fishing and overfishing has really gone wild, these are the places that we have to make hope spots in. That's the size they have to be to protect the bluefin tuna.Now in a second project called Tagging of Pacific Pelagics, we took on the planet as a team, those of us in the Census of Marine Life. And, funded primarily through Sloan Foundation and others, we were able to actually go in, in our project — we're one of 17 field programs and begin to take on tagging large numbers of predators, not just tunas. So what we've done is actually gone up to tag salmon shark in Alaska, met salmon shark on their home territory, followed them catching salmon and then went in and figured out that, if we take a salmon and put it on a line, we can actually take up a salmon shark — This is the cousin of the white shark — and very carefully — note, I say "very carefully," — we can actually keep it calm, put a hose in its mouth, keep it off the deck and then tag it with a satellite tag. That satellite tag will now have your shark phone home and send in a message. And that shark leaping there, if you look carefully, has an antenna. It's a free swimming shark with a satellite tag jumping after salmon, sending home its data. Salmon sharks aren't the only sharks we tag. But there goes salmon sharks with this meter-level resolution on an ocean of temperature — warm colors are warmer. Salmon sharks go down to the tropics to pup and come into Monterey.Now right next door in Monterey and up at the Farallones are a white shark team led by Scott Anderson — there — and Sal Jorgensen. They can throw out a target — it's a carpet shaped like a seal — and in will come a white shark, a curious critter that will come right up to our 16-ft. boat. It's a several thousand-pound animal. And we'll wind in the target. And we'll place an acoustic tag that says, "OMSHARK 10165," or something like that, acoustically with a ping. And then we'll put on a satellite tag that will give us the long-distance journeys with the light-based geolocation algorithms solved on the computer that's on the fish. So in this case, Sal's looking at two tags there, and there they are: the white sharks of California going off to the white shark cafe and coming back. We also tag makos with our NOAA colleagues, blue sharks. And now, together, what we can see on this ocean of color that's temperature, we can see ten-day worms of makos and salmon sharks. We have white sharks and blue sharks. For the first time, an ecoscape as large as ocean-scale, showing where the sharks go.The tuna team from TOPP has done the unthinkable: three teams tagged 1,700 tunas, bluefin, yellowfin and albacore all at the same time — carefully rehearsed tagging programs in which we go out, pick up juvenile tunas, put in the tags that actually have the sensors, stick out the tuna and then let them go. They get returned, and when they get returned, here on a NASA numerical ocean you can see bluefin in blue go across their corridor, returning to the Western Pacific.Our team from UCSC has tagged elephant seals with tags that are glued on their heads, that come off when they slough. These elephant seals cover half an ocean, take data down to 1,800 feet — amazing data. And then there's Scott Shaffer and our shearwaters wearing tuna tags, light-based tags, that now are going to take you from New Zealand to Monterey and back, journeys of 35,000 nautical miles we had never seen before. But now with light-based geolocation tags that are very small, we can actually see these journeys. Same thing with Laysan albatross who travel an entire ocean on a trip sometimes, up to the same zone the tunas use. You can see why they might be caught. Then there's George Schillinger and our leatherback team out of Playa Grande tagging leatherbacks that go right past where we are. And Scott Benson's team that showed that leatherbacks go from Indonesia all the way to Monterey. So what we can see on this moving ocean is we can finally see where the predators are. We can actually see how they're using ecospaces as large as an ocean.And from this information, we can begin to map the hope spots. So this is just three years of data right here — and there's a decade of this data. We see the pulse and the seasonal activities that these animals are going on. So what we're able to do with this information is boil it down to hot spots, 4,000 deployments, a huge herculean task, 2,000 tags in an area, shown here for the first time, off the California coast, that appears to be a gathering place. And then for sort of an encore from these animals, they're helping us. They're carrying instruments that are actually taking data down to 2,000 meters. They're taking information from our planet at very critical places like Antarctica and the Poles. Those are seals from many countries being released who are sampling underneath the ice sheets and giving us temperature data of oceanographic quality on both poles.This data, when visualized, is captivating to watch. We still haven't figured out best how to visualize the data. And then, as these animals swim and give us the information that's important to climate issues, we also think it's critical to get this information to the public, to engage the public with this kind of data. We did this with the Great Turtle Race — tagged turtles, brought in four million hits. And now with Google's Oceans, we can actually put a white shark in that ocean. And when we do and it swims, we see this magnificent bathymetry that the shark knows is there on its path as it goes from California to Hawaii. But maybe Mission Blue can fill in that ocean that we can't see. We've got the capacity, NASA has the ocean. We just need to put it together.So in conclusion, we know where Yellowstone is for North America; it's off our coast. We have the technology that's shown us where it is. What we need to think about perhaps for Mission Blue is increasing the biologging capacity. How is it that we can actually take this type of activity elsewhere? And then finally — to basically get the message home — maybe use live links from animals such as blue whales and white sharks. Make killer apps, if you will. A lot of people are excited when sharks actually went under the Golden Gate Bridge. Let's connect the public to this activity right on their iPhone. That way we do away with a few internet myths.So we can save the bluefin tuna. We can save the white shark. We have the science and technology. Hope is here. Yes we can. We need just to apply this capacity further in the oceans.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I've been fascinated for a lifetime

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
by the beauty, form and function

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
of giant bluefin tuna.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
Bluefin are warmblooded like us.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
They're the largest of the tunas,

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
the second-largest fish in the sea -- bony fish.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
They actually are a fish

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
that is endothermic --

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
powers through the ocean with warm muscles like a mammal.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
That's one of our bluefin at the Monterey Bay Aquarium.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
You can see in its shape and its streamlined design

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
it's powered for ocean swimming.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
It flies through the ocean on its pectoral fins, gets lift,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
powers its movements

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
with a lunate tail.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
It's actually got a naked skin for most of its body,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
so it reduces friction with the water.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
This is what one of nature's finest machines.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
Now, bluefin

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
were revered by Man

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
for all of human history.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
For 4,000 years, we fished sustainably for this animal,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
and it's evidenced

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
in the art that we see

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
from thousands of years ago.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
Bluefin are in cave paintings in France.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
They're on coins

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
that date back 3,000 years.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
This fish was revered by humankind.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
It was fished sustainably

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
till all of time,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
except for our generation.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
Bluefin are pursued wherever they go --

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
there is a gold rush on Earth,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and this is a gold rush for bluefin.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
There are traps that fish sustainably

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
up until recently.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
And yet, the type of fishing going on today,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
with pens, with enormous stakes,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
is really wiping bluefin

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
ecologically off the planet.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
Now bluefin, in general,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
goes to one place: Japan.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
Some of you may be guilty

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
of having contributed to the demise of bluefin.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
They're delectable muscle,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
rich in fat --

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
absolutely taste delicious.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
And that's their problem; we're eating them to death.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
Now in the Atlantic, the story is pretty simple.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Bluefin have two populations: one large, one small.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
The North American population

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
is fished at about 2,000 ton.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
The European population and North African -- the Eastern bluefin tuna --

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
is fished at tremendous levels:

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
50,000 tons over the last decade almost every year.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
The result is whether you're looking

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
at the West or the Eastern bluefin population,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
there's been tremendous decline on both sides,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
as much as 90 percent

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
if you go back with your baseline

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
to 1950.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
For that, bluefin have been given a status

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
equivalent to tigers, to lions,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
to certain African elephants

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and to pandas.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
These fish have been proposed

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
for an endangered species listing in the past two months.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
They were voted on and rejected

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
just two weeks ago,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
despite outstanding science

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
that shows from two committees

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
this fish meets the criteria of CITES I.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
And if it's tunas you don't care about,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
perhaps you might be interested

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
that international long lines and pursing

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
chase down tunas and bycatch animals

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
such as leatherbacks, sharks,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
marlin, albatross.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
These animals and their demise

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
occurs in the tuna fisheries.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
The challenge we face

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
is that we know very little about tuna,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
and everyone in the room knows what it looks like

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
when an African lion

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
takes down its prey.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
I doubt anyone has seen a giant bluefin feed.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
This tuna symbolizes

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
what's the problem for all of us in the room.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
It's the 21st century, but we really have only just begun

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
to really study our oceans in a deep way.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
Technology has come of age

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
that's allowing us to see the Earth from space

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
and go deep into the seas remotely.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
And we've got to use these technologies immediately

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
to get a better understanding

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
of how our ocean realm works.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
Most of us from the ship -- even I --

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
look out at the ocean and see this homogeneous sea.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
We don't know where the structure is.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
We can't tell where are the watering holes

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
like we can on an African plain.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
We can't see the corridors,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
and we can't see what it is

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
that brings together a tuna,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
a leatherback and an albatross.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
We're only just beginning to understand

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
how the physical oceanography

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
and the biological oceanography

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
come together

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
to create a seasonal force

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
that actually causes the upwelling

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
that might make a hot spot a hope spot.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
The reasons these challenges are great

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
is that technically it's difficult to go to sea.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
It's hard to study a bluefin on its turf,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
the entire Pacific realm.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
It's really tough to get up close and personal with a mako shark

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and try to put a tag on it.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
And then imagine being Bruce Mate's team from OSU,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
getting up close to a blue whale

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
and fixing a tag on the blue whale that stays,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
an engineering challenge

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
we've yet to really overcome.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
So the story of our team, a dedicated team,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
is fish and chips.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
We basically are taking

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
the same satellite phone parts,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
or the same parts that are in your computer, chips.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
We're putting them together in unusual ways,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and this is taking us into the ocean realm

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
like never before.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And for the first time,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
we're able to watch the journey of a tuna beneath the ocean

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
using light and photons

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
to measure sunrise and sunset.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Now, I've been working with tunas for over 15 years.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
I have the privilege of being a partner

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
with the Monterey Bay Aquarium.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
We've actually taken a sliver of the ocean,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
put it behind glass,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and we together

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
have put bluefin tuna and yellowfin tuna on display.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
When the veil of bubbles lifts every morning,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
we can actually see a community from the Pelagic ocean,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
one of the only places on Earth

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
you can see giant bluefin swim by.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
We can see in their beauty of form and function,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
their ceaseless activity.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
They're flying through their space, ocean space.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
And we can bring two million people a year

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
into contact with this fish

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
and show them its beauty.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Behind the scenes is a working lab at Stanford University

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
partnered with the Monterey Bay Aquarium.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Here, for over 14 or 15 years,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
we've actually brought in

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
both bluefin and yellowfin in captivity.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
We'd been studying these fish,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
but first we had to learn how to husbandry them.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
What do they like to eat?

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
What is it that they're happy with?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
We go in the tanks with the tuna -- we touch their naked skin --

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
it's pretty amazing. It feels wonderful.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
And then, better yet,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
we've got our own version of tuna whisperers,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
our own Chuck Farwell, Alex Norton,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
who can take a big tuna

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and in one motion,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
put it into an envelope of water,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
so that we can actually work with the tuna

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and learn the techniques it takes

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
to not injure this fish

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
who never sees a boundary in the open sea.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Jeff and Jason there, are scientists

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
who are going to take a tuna

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and put it in the equivalent of a treadmill, a flume.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
And that tuna thinks it's going to Japan, but it's staying in place.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
We're actually measuring its oxygen consumption,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
its energy consumption.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
We're taking this data and building better models.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And when I see that tuna -- this is my favorite view --

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
I begin to wonder:

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
how did this fish solve the longitude problem before we did?

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
So take a look at that animal.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
That's the closest you'll probably ever get.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Now, the activities from the lab

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
have taught us now how to go out in the open ocean.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
So in a program called Tag-A-Giant

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
we've actually gone from Ireland to Canada,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
from Corsica to Spain.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
We've fished with many nations around the world

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
in an effort to basically

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
put electronic computers

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
inside giant tunas.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
We've actually tagged 1,100 tunas.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And I'm going to show you three clips,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
because I tagged 1,100 tunas.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
It's a very hard process, but it's a ballet.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
We bring the tuna out, we measure it.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
A team of fishers, captains, scientists and technicians

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
work together to keep this animal out of the ocean

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
for about four to five minutes.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
We put water over its gills, give it oxygen.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And then with a lot of effort, after tagging,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
putting in the computer,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
making sure the stalk is sticking out so it senses the environment,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
we send this fish back into the sea.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And when it goes, we're always happy.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
We see a flick of the tail.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
And from our data that gets collected,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
when that tag comes back,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
because a fisher returns it

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
for a thousand-dollar reward,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
we can get tracks beneath the sea

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
for up to five years now,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
on a backboned animal.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Now sometimes the tunas are really large,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
such as this fish off Nantucket.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
But that's about half the size

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
of the biggest tuna we've ever tagged.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It takes a human effort,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
a team effort, to bring the fish in.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
In this case, what we're going to do

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
is put a pop-up satellite archival tag on the tuna.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
This tag rides on the tuna,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
senses the environment around the tuna

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
and actually will come off the fish,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
detach, float to the surface

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and send back to Earth-orbiting satellites

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
position data estimated by math on the tag,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
pressure data and temperature data.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And so what we get then from the pop-up satellite tag

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
is we get away from having to have a human interaction

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
to recapture the tag.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Both the electronic tags I'm talking about are expensive.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
These tags have been engineered

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
by a variety of teams in North America.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
They are some of our finest instruments,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
our new technology in the ocean today.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
One community in general

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
has given more to help us than any other community.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And that's the fisheries off the state of North Carolina.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
There are two villages, Harris and Morehead City,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
every winter for over a decade,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
held a party called Tag-A-Giant,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and together, fishers worked with us

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
to tag 800 to 900 fish.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
In this case, we're actually going to measure the fish.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
We're going to do something that in recent years we've started:

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
take a mucus sample.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
Watch how shiny the skin is; you can see my reflection there.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And from that mucus, we can get gene profiles,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
we can get information on gender,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
checking the pop-up tag one more time,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and then it's out in the ocean.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And this is my favorite.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
With the help of my former postdoc, Gareth Lawson,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
this is a gorgeous picture of a single tuna.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
This tuna is actually moving on a numerical ocean.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
The warm is the Gulf Stream,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
the cold up there in the Gulf of Maine.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
That's where the tuna wants to go -- it wants to forage on schools of herring --

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
but it can't get there. It's too cold.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
But then it warms up, and the tuna pops in, gets some fish,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
maybe comes back to home base,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
goes in again

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and then comes back to winter down there in North Carolina

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
and then on to the Bahamas.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And my favorite scene, three tunas going into the Gulf of Mexico.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Three tunas tagged.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Astronomically, we're calculating positions.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
They're coming together. That could be tuna sex --

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
and there it is.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
That is where the tuna spawn.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
So from data like this,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
we're able now to put the map up,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and in this map

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
you see thousands of positions

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
generated by this decade and a half of tagging.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And now we're showing that tunas on the western side

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
go to the eastern side.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
So two populations of tunas --

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
that is, we have a Gulf population, one that we can tag --

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
they go to the Gulf of Mexico, I showed you that --

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and a second population.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
Living amongst our tunas -- our North American tunas --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
are European tunas that go back to the Med.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
On the hot spots -- the hope spots --

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
they're mixed populations.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
And so what we've done with the science

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
is we're showing the International Commission,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
building new models,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
showing them that a two-stock no-mixing model --

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
to this day, used to reject

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
the CITES treaty --

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
that model isn't the right model.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
This model, a model of overlap,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
is the way to move forward.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
So we can then predict

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
where management places should be.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Places like the Gulf of Mexico and the Mediterranean

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
are places where the single species,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
the single population, can be captured.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
These become forthright in places we need to protect.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
The center of the Atlantic where the mixing is,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
I could imagine a policy that lets Canada and America fish,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
because they manage their fisheries well,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
they're doing a good job.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
But in the international realm,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
where fishing and overfishing has really gone wild,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
these are the places that we have to make hope spots in.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
That's the size they have to be to protect the bluefin tuna.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
Now in a second project

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
called Tagging of Pacific Pelagics,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
we took on the planet as a team,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
those of us in the Census of Marine Life.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And, funded primarily through Sloan Foundation and others,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
we were able to actually go in, in our project --

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
we're one of 17 field programs

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and begin to take on tagging large numbers of predators,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
not just tunas.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
So what we've done

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
is actually gone up to tag salmon shark in Alaska,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
met salmon shark on their home territory,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
followed them catching salmon

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
and then went in and figured out

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
that, if we take a salmon and put it on a line,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
we can actually take up a salmon shark --

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
This is the cousin of the white shark --

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
and very carefully --

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
note, I say "very carefully," --

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
we can actually keep it calm,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
put a hose in its mouth, keep it off the deck

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and then tag it with a satellite tag.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
That satellite tag will now have your shark phone home

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and send in a message.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And that shark leaping there, if you look carefully, has an antenna.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
It's a free swimming shark with a satellite tag

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
jumping after salmon,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
sending home its data.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Salmon sharks aren't the only sharks we tag.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
But there goes salmon sharks with this meter-level resolution

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
on an ocean of temperature -- warm colors are warmer.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Salmon sharks go down

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
to the tropics to pup

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and come into Monterey.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Now right next door in Monterey and up at the Farallones

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
are a white shark team led by Scott Anderson -- there --

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
and Sal Jorgensen.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
They can throw out a target --

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
it's a carpet shaped like a seal --

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
and in will come a white shark, a curious critter

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
that will come right up to our 16-ft. boat.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
It's a several thousand-pound animal.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And we'll wind in the target.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And we'll place an acoustic tag

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
that says, "OMSHARK 10165,"

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
or something like that, acoustically with a ping.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
And then we'll put on a satellite tag

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
that will give us the long-distance journeys

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
with the light-based geolocation algorithms

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
solved on the computer that's on the fish.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
So in this case, Sal's looking at two tags there,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and there they are: the white sharks of California

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
going off to the white shark cafe and coming back.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
We also tag makos with our NOAA colleagues,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
blue sharks.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And now, together, what we can see

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
on this ocean of color that's temperature,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
we can see ten-day worms of makos and salmon sharks.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
We have white sharks and blue sharks.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
For the first time,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
an ecoscape as large as ocean-scale,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
showing where the sharks go.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
The tuna team from TOPP has done the unthinkable:

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
three teams tagged 1,700 tunas,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
bluefin, yellowfin and albacore

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
all at the same time --

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
carefully rehearsed tagging programs

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
in which we go out, pick up juvenile tunas,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
put in the tags that actually have the sensors,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
stick out the tuna

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and then let them go.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
They get returned, and when they get returned,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
here on a NASA numerical ocean

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
you can see bluefin in blue

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
go across their corridor,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
returning to the Western Pacific.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
Our team from UCSC has tagged elephant seals

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
with tags that are glued on their heads, that come off when they slough.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
These elephant seals cover half an ocean,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
take data down to 1,800 feet --

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
amazing data.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
And then there's Scott Shaffer and our shearwaters

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
wearing tuna tags, light-based tags,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
that now are going to take you from New Zealand to Monterey and back,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
journeys of 35,000 nautical miles

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
we had never seen before.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
But now with light-based geolocation tags that are very small,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
we can actually see these journeys.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
Same thing with Laysan albatross

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
who travel an entire ocean

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
on a trip sometimes,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
up to the same zone the tunas use.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
You can see why they might be caught.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
Then there's George Schillinger and our leatherback team out of Playa Grande

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
tagging leatherbacks

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
that go right past where we are.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
And Scott Benson's team

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
that showed that leatherbacks go from Indonesia

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
all the way to Monterey.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
So what we can see on this moving ocean

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
is we can finally see where the predators are.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
We can actually see how they're using ecospaces

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
as large as an ocean.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
And from this information,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
we can begin to map the hope spots.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
So this is just three years of data right here --

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and there's a decade of this data.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
We see the pulse and the seasonal activities

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
that these animals are going on.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
So what we're able to do with this information

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
is boil it down to hot spots,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
4,000 deployments,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
a huge herculean task,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
2,000 tags

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
in an area, shown here for the first time,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
off the California coast,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
that appears to be a gathering place.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And then for sort of an encore from these animals,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
they're helping us.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
They're carrying instruments

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
that are actually taking data down to 2,000 meters.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
They're taking information from our planet

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
at very critical places like Antarctica and the Poles.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
Those are seals from many countries

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
being released

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
who are sampling underneath the ice sheets

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
and giving us temperature data of oceanographic quality

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
on both poles.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
This data, when visualized, is captivating to watch.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
We still haven't figured out best how to visualize the data.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
And then, as these animals swim

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
and give us the information

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
that's important to climate issues,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
we also think it's critical

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
to get this information to the public,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
to engage the public with this kind of data.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
We did this with the Great Turtle Race --

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
tagged turtles, brought in four million hits.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
And now with Google's Oceans,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
we can actually put a white shark in that ocean.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
And when we do and it swims,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
we see this magnificent bathymetry

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
that the shark knows is there on its path

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
as it goes from California to Hawaii.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
But maybe Mission Blue

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
can fill in that ocean that we can't see.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
We've got the capacity, NASA has the ocean.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
We just need to put it together.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
So in conclusion,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
we know where Yellowstone is for North America;

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:06.958
it's off our coast.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
We have the technology that's shown us where it is.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:11.958
What we need to think about perhaps for Mission Blue

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
is increasing the biologging capacity.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
How is it that we can actually

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
take this type of activity elsewhere?

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
And then finally -- to basically get the message home --

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
maybe use live links

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
from animals such as blue whales and white sharks.

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
Make killer apps, if you will.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
A lot of people are excited

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
when sharks actually went under the Golden Gate Bridge.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
Let's connect the public to this activity right on their iPhone.

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
That way we do away with a few internet myths.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:42.958
So we can save the bluefin tuna.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:44.958
We can save the white shark.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:46.958
We have the science and technology.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
Hope is here. Yes we can.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
We need just to apply this capacity

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
further in the oceans.

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
Thank you.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
(Applause)

title: The good news of the decade? We're winning the war against child mortality
transcript: We are here today because [the] United Nations have defined goals for the progress of countries. They're called Millennium Development Goals. And the reason I really like these goals is that there are eight of them. And by specifying eight different goals, the United Nations has said that there are so many things needed to change in a country in order to get the good life for people. Look here — you have to end poverty, education, gender, child and maternal health, control infections, protect the environment and get the good global links between nations in every aspect from aid to trade.There's a second reason I like these development goals, and that is because each and every one is measured. Take child mortality; the aim here is to reduce child mortality by two-thirds, from 1990 to 2015. That's a four percent reduction per year — and this, with measuring. That's what makes the difference between political talking like this and really going for the important thing, a better life for people. And what I'm so happy about with this is that we have already documented that there are many countries in Asia, in the Middle East, in Latin America and East Europe that [are] reducing with this rate. And even mighty Brazil is going down with five percent per year, and Turkey with seven percent per year. So there's good news. But then I hear people saying, "There is no progress in Africa. I bring you to the webpage, ChildMortality.org, where you can take deaths in children below five years of age for all countries — it's done by U.N. specialists. And I will take Kenya as an example. Is it so that in Kenya, there are doctors and other specialists who write the death certificate at the death of the child and it's sent to the statistical office? What we rely on is not an incomplete system. We have interviews, we have surveys. And this is highly professional female interviewers who sit down for one hour with a woman and ask her about [her] birth history. How many children did you have? Are they alive? If they died, at what age and what year? And then this is done in a representative sample of thousands of women in the country and put together in what used to be called a demographic health survey report. But these surveys are costly, so they can only be done [in] three- to five-year intervals. But they have good quality. So this is a limitation. But that's too complicated for today, so I'll simplify it for you, and I give you one average point for each survey.This was 1977, 1988, 1992, '97 and 2002. Then it just took another three months for [the] U.N. to get it into their server, and on Friday we got the new trend line — it was down here. Isn't it nice — isn't it nice, yeah? They got electricity in their homes, they increased education and they got primary health care. And down they went, you know. And they got safer water, they eradicated malaria.
