00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
Here we have [the] year.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
And I'm now giving you a wider picture than the MDG.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I start 50 years ago

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
when Africa celebrated independence in most countries.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
I give you Congo, which was high,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Ghana -- lower. And Kenya -- even lower.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
And what has happened over the years since then? Here we go.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
You can see, with independence, literacy improved

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
and vaccinations started, smallpox was eradicated,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
hygiene was improved, and things got better.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
But then, in the '80s, watch out here.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
Congo got into civil war,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and they leveled off here.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
Ghana got very ahead, fast.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
This was the backlash in Kenya, and Ghana bypassed,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
but then Kenya and Ghana go down together --

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
still a standstill in Congo.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
That's where we are today.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
You can see it doesn't make sense

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
to make an average of this zero improvement

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
and this very fast improvement.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Time has come

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
to stop thinking about sub-Saharan Africa as one place.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
Their countries are so different,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
and they merit to be recognized in the same way,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
as we don't talk about Europe as one place.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
I can tell you that the economy in Greece and Sweden are very different --

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
everyone knows that.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And they are judged, each country, on how they are doing.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
So let me show the wider picture.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
My country, Sweden:

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
1800, we were up there.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
What a strange personality disorder we must have,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
counting the children so meticulously in spite of a high child death rate.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
It's very strange. It's sort of embarrassing.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
But we had that habit in Sweden, you know,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
that we counted all the child deaths,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
even if we didn't do anything about it.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And then, you see, these were famine years.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
These were bad years, and people got fed up with Sweden.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
My ancestors moved to the United States.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And eventually, soon they started to get better and better here.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And here we got better education, and we got health service,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and child mortality came down.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
We never had a war; Sweden was in peace all this time.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
But look, the rate of lowering

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
in Sweden

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
was not fast.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Sweden achieved a low child mortality

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
because we started early.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
We had primary school actually

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
started in 1842.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And then you get that wonderful effect

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
when we got female literacy

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
one generation later.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
You have to realize that the investments we do in progress

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
are long-term investments.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
It's not about just five years --

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
it's long-term investments.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And Sweden never reached [the] Millennium Development Goal rate,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
3.1 percent when I calculated.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
So we are off track -- that's what Sweden is.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
But you don't talk about it so much.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
We want others to be better than we were, and indeed, others have been better.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Let me show you Thailand,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
see what a success story, Thailand from the 1960s --

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
how they went down here

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
and reached almost the same child mortality levels as Sweden.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
And I'll give you another story -- Egypt,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
the most hidden, glorious success in public health.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Egypt was up here in 1960,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
higher than Congo.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
The Nile Delta was a misery for children

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
with diarrheal disease

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and malaria and a lot of problems.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
And then they got the Aswan Dam. They got electricity in their homes,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
they increased education

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
and they got primary health care.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And down they went, you know.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And they got safer water, they eradicated malaria.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And isn't it a success story.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Millennium Development Goal rates for child mortality

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
is fully possible.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
And the good thing is

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
that Ghana today is going with the same rate

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
as Egypt did at its fastest.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Kenya is now speeding up.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Here we have a problem.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
We have a severe problem in countries which are at a standstill.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Now, let me now bring you to a wider picture,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
a wider picture of child mortality.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
I'm going to show you the relationship

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
between child mortality on this axis here --

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
this axis here is child mortality --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
and here I have the family size.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
The relationship between child mortality and family size.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
One, two, three, four children per woman:

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
six, seven, eight children per woman.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
This is, once again, 1960 --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
50 years ago.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Each bubble is a country --

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
the color, you can see, a continent.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
The dark blue here is sub-Saharan Africa.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And the size of the bubble is the population.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
And these are

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
the so-called "developing" countries.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
They had high, or very high, child mortality

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and family size, six to eight.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And the ones over there,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
they were so-called Western countries.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
They had low child mortality

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
and small families.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
What has happened?

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
What I want you [to do] now is to see with your own eyes

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
the relation between fall in child mortality

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
and decrease in family size.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
I just want not to have any room for doubt --

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
you have to see that for yourself.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
This is what happened. Now I start the world.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Here we come down with the eradication of

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
smallpox, better education,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
health service.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
It got down there -- China comes into the Western box here.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And here Brazil is in the Western Box.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
India is approaching. The first African countries coming into the Western box,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
and we get a lot a new neighbors.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Welcome to a decent life.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Come on. We want everyone down there.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
This is the vision we have, isn't it.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And look now, the first African countries here are coming in.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
There we are today.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
There is no such thing

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
as a "Western world" and "developing world."

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
This is the report from [the] U.N.,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
which came out on Friday.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
It's very good -- "Levels and Trends in Child Mortality" --

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
except this page.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
This page is very bad;

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
it's a categorization of countries.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
It labels "developing countries," -- I can read from the list here --

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
developing countries: Republic of Korea -- South Korea.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Huh?

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
They get Samsung, how can they be [a] developing country?

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
They have here Singapore.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
They have the lowest child mortality in the world, Singapore.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
They bypassed Sweden five years ago,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and they are labeled a developing country.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
They have here Qatar.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
It's the richest country in the world with Al Jazeera.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
How the heck could they be [a] developing country?

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
This is crap.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
(Applause)

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
The rest here is good -- the rest is good.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
We have to have a modern concept,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
which fits to the data.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And we have to realize

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
that we are all going to into this, down to here.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
What is the importance now with the relations here.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
Look -- even if we look in Africa --

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
these are the African countries.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
You can clearly see the relation with falling child mortality

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and decreasing family size,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
even within Africa.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
It's very clear that this is what happens.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And a very important piece of research came out on Friday

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
from the Institute of Health Metrics and Evaluation in Seattle

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
showing that almost 50 percent

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
of the fall in child mortality

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
can be attributed to female education.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
That is, when we get girls in school,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
we'll get an impact 15 to 20 years later,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
which is a secular trend which is very strong.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
That's why we must have that long-term perspective,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
but we must measure the impact

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
over 10-year periods.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
It's fully possible

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
to get child mortality down in all of these countries

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and to get them down in the corner

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
where we all would like to live together.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And of course, lowering child mortality

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
is a matter of utmost importance

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
from humanitarian aspects.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
It's a decent life for children,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
we are talking about.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
But it is also a strategic investment

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
in the future of all mankind,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
because it's about the environment.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
We will not be able to manage the environment

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
and avoid the terrible climate crisis

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
if we don't stabilize the world population.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
Let's be clear about that.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
And the way to do that,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
that is to get child mortality down, get access to family planning

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and behind that drive female education.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
And that is fully possible. Let's do it.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Thank you very much.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:23.958
(Applause)

title: The best gift I ever survived
transcript: Imagine, if you will — a gift. I'd like for you to picture it in your mind. It's not too big — about the size of a golf ball. So envision what it looks like all wrapped up. But before I show you what's inside, I will tell you, it's going to do incredible things for you. It will bring all of your family together. You will feel loved and appreciated like never before and reconnect with friends and acquaintances you haven't heard from in years. Adoration and admiration will overwhelm you. It will recalibrate what's most important in your life.It will redefine your sense of spirituality and faith. You'll have a new understanding and trust in your body. You'll have unsurpassed vitality and energy. You'll expand your vocabulary, meet new people, and you'll have a healthier lifestyle. And get this — you'll have an eight-week vacation of doing absolutely nothing. You'll eat countless gourmet meals. Flowers will arrive by the truckload. People will say to you, "You look great. Have you had any work done?" And you'll have a lifetime supply of good drugs.You'll be challenged, inspired, motivated and humbled. Your life will have new meaning. Peace, health, serenity, happiness, nirvana. The price? $55,000, and that's an incredible deal.By now I know you're dying to know what it is and where you can get one. Does Amazon carry it? Does it have the Apple logo on it? Is there a waiting list? Not likely. This gift came to me about five months ago. It looked more like this when it was all wrapped up — not quite so pretty. And this, and then this. It was a rare gem — a brain tumor, hemangioblastoma — the gift that keeps on giving.And while I'm okay now, I wouldn't wish this gift for you. I'm not sure you'd want it. But I wouldn't change my experience. It profoundly altered my life in ways I didn't expect in all the ways I just shared with you.So the next time you're faced with something that's unexpected, unwanted and uncertain, consider that it just may be a gift.(Applause)

title: The roots of plant intelligence
transcript: Sometimes I go browsing [through] a very old magazine. I found this observation test about the story of the ark. And the artist that drew this observation test did some errors, had some mistakes — there are more or less 12 mistakes. Some of them are very easy. There is a funnel, an aerial part, a lamp and clockwork key on the ark. Some of them are about the animals, the number. But there is a much more fundamental mistake in the overall story of the ark that's not reported here. And this problem is: where are the plants? So now we have God that is going to submerge Earth permanently or at least for a very long period, and no one is taking care of plants. Noah needed to take two of every kind of bird, of every kind of animal, of every kind of creature that moves, but no mention about plants. Why? In another part of the same story, all the living creatures are just the living creatures that came out from the ark, so birds, livestock and wild animals. Plants are not living creatures — this is the point. That is a point that is not coming out from the Bible, but it's something that really accompanied humanity.Let's have a look at this nice code that is coming from a Renaissance book. Here we have the description of the order of nature. It's a nice description because it's starting from left — you have the stones — immediately after the stones, the plants that are just able to live. We have the animals that are able to live and to sense, and on the top of the pyramid, there is the man. This is not the common man. The "Homo studiosus" — the studying man. This is quite comforting for people like me — I'm a professor — this to be over there on the top of creation. But it's something completely wrong. You know very well about professors. 00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and we found that there is a specific region

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
that is here, depicted in blue --

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
that is called the "transition zone."

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And this region, it's a very small region --

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
it's less than one millimeter.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
And in this small region

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
you have the highest consumption

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
of oxygen in the plants

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and more important,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
you have these kinds of signals here.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
The signals that you are seeing here are action potential,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
are the same signals

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
that the neurons of my brain, of our brain,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
use to exchange information.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Now we know that a root apex

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
has just a few hundred cells

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
that show this kind of feature,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
but we know how big

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
the root apparatus of a small plant, like a plant of rye.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
We have almost

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
14 million roots.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We have 11 and a half million

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
root apex

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and a total length of 600 or more kilometers

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and a very high surface area.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Now let's imagine

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
that each single root apex

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
is working in network with all the others.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Here were have on the left, the Internet

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and on the right, the root apparatus.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
They work in the same way.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
They are a network

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
of small computing machines,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
working in networks.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
And why are they so similar?

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Because they evolved

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
for the same reason:

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
to survive predation.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
They work in the same way.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
So you can remove 90 percent of the root apparatus

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and the plants [continue] to work.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
You can remove 90 percent of the Internet

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and it is [continuing] to work.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
So, a suggestion

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
for the people working with networks:

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
plants are able

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
to give you good suggestions

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
about how to evolve networks.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
And another possibility

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
is a technological possibility.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
Let's imagine

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
that we can build robots

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and robots that are inspired by plants.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Until now,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
the man was inspired

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
just by man or the animals

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
in producing a robot.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
We have the animaloid --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and the normal robots inspired by animals,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
insectoid, so on.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
We have the androids

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
that are inspired by man.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
But why have we not any plantoid?

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Well, if you want to fly,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
it's good that you look at birds --

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
to be inspired by birds.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
But if you want to explore soils,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
or if you want to colonize

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
new territory,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
to best thing that you can do is to be inspired by plants

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that are masters in doing this.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
We have another possibility

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
we are working [on] in our lab,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
[which] is to build hybrids.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
It's much more easy to build hybrids.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Hybrid means it's something

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
that's half living and half machine.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
It's much more easy to work with plants

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
than with animals.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
They have computing power,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
they have electrical signals.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
The connection with the machine is much more easy,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
much more even ethically possible.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And these are three possibilities

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
that we are working on

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
to build hybrids,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
driven by algae

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
or by the leaves at the end,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
by the most, most powerful parts of the plants,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
by the roots.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Well, thank you for your attention.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
And before I finish,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
I would like to reassure that no snails were harmed

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
in making this presentation.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Thank you.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:39.958
(Applause)

title: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
transcript: One of my favorite parts of my job at the Gates Foundation is that I get to travel to the developing world, and I do that quite regularly. And when I meet the mothers in so many of these remote places, I'm really struck by the things that we have in common. They want what we want for our children and that is for their children to grow up successful, to be healthy, and to have a successful life. But I also see lots of poverty, and it's quite jarring, both in the scale and the scope of it. My first trip in India, I was in a person's home where they had dirt floors, no running water, no electricity, and that's really what I see all over the world. So in short, I'm startled by all the things that they don't have. But I am surprised by one thing that they do have: Coca-Cola.Coke is everywhere. In fact, when I travel to the developing world, Coke feels ubiquitous. And so when I come back from these trips, and I'm thinking about development, and I'm flying home and I'm thinking, "We're trying to deliver condoms to people or vaccinations," you know, Coke's success kind of stops and makes you wonder: how is it that they can get Coke to these far-flung places? If they can do that, why can't governments and NGOs do the same thing? And I'm not the first person to ask this question. But I think, as a community, we still have a lot to learn. It's staggering, if you think about Coca-Cola. They sell 1.5 billion servings every single day. That's like every man, woman and child on the planet having a serving of Coke every week. So why does this matter? Well, if we're going to speed up the progress and go even faster on the set of Millennium Development Goals that we're set as a world, we need to learn from the innovators, and those innovators come from every single sector. I feel that, if we can understand what makes something like Coca-Cola ubiquitous, we can apply those lessons then for the public good.Coke's success is relevant, because if we can analyze it, learn from it, then we can save lives. So that's why I took a bit of time to study Coke. And I think there are really three things we can take away from Coca-Cola. They take real-time data and immediately feed it back into the product. They tap into local entrepreneurial talent, and they do incredible marketing. So let's start with the data. Now Coke has a very clear bottom line — they report to a set of shareholders, they have to turn a profit. So they take the data, and they use it to measure progress. They have this very continuous feedback loop. They learn something, they put it back into the product, they put it back into the market. They have a whole team called "Knowledge and Insight." It's a lot like other consumer companies. So if you're running Namibia for Coca-Cola, and you have a 107 constituencies, you know where every can versus bottle of Sprite, Fanta or Coke was sold, whether it was a corner store, a supermarket or a pushcart. So if sales start to drop, then the person can identify the problem and address the issue.Let's contrast that for a minute to development. In development, the evaluation comes at the very end of the project. I've sat in a lot of those meetings, and by then, it is way too late to use the data. I had somebody from an NGO once describe it to me as bowling in the dark. They said, "You roll the ball, you hear some pins go down. It's dark, you can't see which one goes down until the lights come on, and then you an see your impact." Real-time data turns on the lights.So what's the second thing that Coke's good at? They're good at tapping into that local entrepreneurial talent. Coke's been in Africa since 1928, but most of the time they couldn't reach the distant markets, because they had a system that was a lot like in the developed world, which was a large truck rolling down the street. And in Africa, the remote places, it's hard to find a good road. But Coke noticed something — they noticed that local people were taking the product, buying it in bulk and then reselling it in these hard-to-reach places. And so they took a bit of time to learn about that. And they decided in 1990 that they wanted to start training the local entrepreneurs, giving them small loans. They set them up as what they called micro-distribution centers, and those local entrepreneurs then hire sales people, who go out with bicycles and pushcarts and wheelbarrows to sell the product. There are now some 3,000 of these centers employing about 15,000 people in Africa. In Tanzania and Uganda, they represent 90 percent of Coke's sales. Let's look at the development side.What is it that governments and NGOs can learn from Coke? Governments and NGOs need to tap into that local entrepreneurial talent as well, because the locals know how to reach the very hard-to-serve places, their neighbors, and they know what motivates them to make change. I think a great example of this is Ethiopia's new health extension program. The government noticed in Ethiopia that many of the people were so far away from a health clinic, they were over a day's travel away from a health clinic. So if you're in an emergency situation — or if you're a mom about to deliver a baby — forget it, to get to the health care center. They decided that wasn't good enough, so they went to India and studied the Indian state of Kerala that also had a system like this, and they adapted it for Ethiopia. And in 2003, the government of Ethiopia started this new system in their own country. They trained 35,000 health extension workers to deliver care directly to the people. In just five years, their ratio went from one worker for every 30,000 people to one worker for every 2,500 people.Now, think about how this can change people's lives. Health extension workers can help with so many things, whether it's family planning, prenatal care, immunizations for the children, or advising the woman to get to the facility on time for an on-time delivery. That is having real impact in a country like Ethiopia, and it's why you see their child mortality numbers coming down 25 percent from 2000 to 2008. In Ethiopia, there are hundreds of thousands of children living because of this health extension worker program. So what's the next step for Ethiopia? Well, they're already starting talk about this. They're starting to talk about, "How do you have the health community workers generate their own ideas? How do you incent them based on the impact that they're getting out in those remote villages?" That's how you tap into local entrepreneurial talent and you unlock people's potential.The third component of Coke's success is marketing. Ultimately, Coke's success depends on one crucial fact and that is that people want a Coca-Cola. Now the reason these micro-entrepreneurs can sell or make a profit is they have to sell every single bottle in their pushcart or their wheelbarrow. So, they rely on Coca-Cola in terms of its marketing, and what's the secret to their marketing? Well, it's aspirational. It is associated that product with a kind of life that people want to live. So even though it's a global company, they take a very local approach. Coke's global campaign slogan is "Open Happiness." But they localize it. And they don't just guess what makes people happy; they go to places like Latin America and they realize that happiness there is associated with family life. And in South Africa, they associate happiness with seriti or community respect. Now, that played itself out in the World Cup campaign. Let's listen to this song that Coke created for it, "Wavin' Flag" by a Somali hip hop artist.(Video) K'Naan: ♫ Oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫ ♫ Oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh ♫ ♫ Oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫ ♫ Oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫ ♫Give you freedom, give you fire♫ ♫ Give you reason, take you higher ♫ ♫ See the champions take the field now ♫ ♫ You define us, make us feel proud ♫ ♫ In the streets our heads are lifted ♫ ♫ As we lose our inhibition ♫ ♫ Celebration, it's around us ♫ ♫ Every nation, all around us ♫Melinda French Gates: It feels pretty good, right? Well, they didn't stop there — they localized it into 18 different languages. And it went number one on the pop chart in 17 countries. It reminds me of a song that I remember from my childhood, "I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing," that also went number one on the pop charts. Both songs have something in common: that same appeal of celebration and unity. So how does health and development market? Well, it's based on avoidance, not aspirations. I'm sure you've heard some of these messages. "Use a condom, don't get AIDS." "Wash you hands, you might not get diarrhea." It doesn't sound anything like "Wavin' Flag" to me.And I think we make a fundamental mistake — we make an assumption, that we think that, if people need something, we don't have to make them want that. And I think that's a mistake. And there's some indications around the world that this is starting to change. One example is sanitation. We know that a million and a half children die a year from diarrhea and a lot of it is because of open defecation. But there's a solution: you build a toilet. But what we're finding around the world, over and over again, is, if you build a toilet and you leave it there, it doesn't get used. People reuse it for a slab for their home. They sometimes store grain in it. I've even seen it used for a chicken coop. (Laughter) But what does marketing really entail that would make a sanitation solution get a result in diarrhea? Well, you work with the community. You start to talk to them about why open defecation is something that shouldn't be done in the village, and they agree to that. But then you take the toilet and you position it as a modern, trendy convenience. One state in Northern India has gone so far as to link toilets to courtship. And it works — look at these headlines. (Laughter) I'm not kidding. Women are refusing to marry men without toilets. No loo, no "I do."(Laughter)Now, it's not just a funny headline — it's innovative. It's an innovative marketing campaign. But more importantly, it saves lives. Take a look at this — this is a room full of young men and my husband, Bill. And can you guess what the young men are waiting for? They're waiting to be circumcised. Can you you believe that? We know that circumcision reduces HIV infection by 60 percent in men. And when we first heard this result inside the Foundation, I have to admit, Bill and I were scratching our heads a little bit and we were saying, "But who's going to volunteer for this procedure?" But it turns out the men do, because they're hearing from their girlfriends that they prefer it, and the men also believe it improves their sex life. So if we can start to understand what people really want in health and development, we can change communities and we can change whole nations.Well, why is all of this so important? So let's talk about what happens when this all comes together, when you tie the three things together. And polio, I think, is one of the most powerful examples. We've seen a 99 percent reduction in polio in 20 years. So if you look back to 1988, there are about 350,000 cases of polio on the planet that year. In 2009, we're down to 1,600 cases. Well how did that happen? Let's look at a country like India. They have over a billion people in this country, but they have 35,000 local doctors who report paralysis, and clinicians, a huge reporting system in chemists. They have two and a half million vaccinators. But let me make the story a little bit more concrete for you. Let me tell you the story of Shriram, an 18 month boy in Bihar, a northern state in India. This year on August 8th, he felt paralysis and on the 13th, his parents took him to the doctor. On August 14th and 15th, they took a stool sample, and by the 25th of August, it was confirmed he had Type 1 polio. By August 30th, a genetic test was done, and we knew what strain of polio Shriram had.Now it could have come from one of two places. It could have come from Nepal, just to the north, across the border, or from Jharkhand, a state just to the south. Luckily, the genetic testing proved that, in fact, this strand came north, because, had it come from the south, it would have had a much wider impact in terms of transmission. So many more people would have been affected. So what's the endgame? Well on September 4th, there was a huge mop-up campaign, which is what you do in polio. They went out and where Shriram lives, they vaccinated two million people. So in less than a month, we went from one case of paralysis to a targeted vaccination program. And I'm happy to say only one other person in that area got polio. That's how you keep a huge outbreak from spreading, and it shows what can happen when local people have the data in their hands; they can save lives.Now one of the challenges in polio, still, is marketing, but it might not be what you think. It's not the marketing on the ground. It's not telling the parents, "If you see paralysis, take your child to the doctor or get your child vaccinated." We have a problem with marketing in the donor community. The G8 nations have been incredibly generous on polio over the last 20 years, but we're starting to have something called polio fatigue and that is that the donor nations aren't willing to fund polio any longer. So by next summer, we're sighted to run out of money on polio. So we are 99 percent of the way there on this goal and we're about to run short of money. And I think that if the marketing were more aspirational, if we could focus as a community on how far we've come and how amazing it would be to eradicate this disease, we could put polio fatigue and polio behind us. And if we could do that, we could stop vaccinating everybody, worldwide, in all of our countries for polio. And it would only be the second disease ever wiped off the face of the planet. And we are so close. And this victory is so possible.So if Coke's marketers came to me and asked me to define happiness, I'd say my vision of happiness is a mother holding healthy baby in her arms. To me, that is deep happiness. And so if we can learn lessons from the innovators in every sector, then in the future we make together, that happiness can be just as ubiquitous as Coca-Cola.Thank you.(Applause)

whether it was a corner store,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
a supermarket or a pushcart.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
So if sales start to drop,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
then the person can identify the problem

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
and address the issue.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
Let's contrast that for a minute to development.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
In development, the evaluation comes

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
at the very end of the project.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I've sat in a lot of those meetings,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and by then,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
it is way too late to use the data.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
I had somebody from an NGO

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
once describe it to me as bowling in the dark.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
They said, "You roll the ball, you hear some pins go down.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
It's dark, you can't see which one goes down until the lights come on,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
and then you an see your impact."

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
Real-time data

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
turns on the lights.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
So what's the second thing that Coke's good at?

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
They're good at tapping into

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
that local entrepreneurial talent.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Coke's been in Africa since 1928,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
but most of the time they couldn't reach the distant markets,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
because they had a system that was a lot like in the developed world,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
which was a large truck rolling down the street.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And in Africa, the remote places,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
it's hard to find a good road.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
But Coke noticed something --

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
they noticed that local people were taking the product, buying it in bulk

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and then reselling it in these hard-to-reach places.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
And so they took a bit of time to learn about that.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
And they decided in 1990

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
that they wanted to start training the local entrepreneurs,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
giving them small loans.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
They set them up as what they called micro-distribution centers,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and those local entrepreneurs then hire sales people,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
who go out with bicycles and pushcarts and wheelbarrows

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
to sell the product.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
There are now some 3,000 of these centers

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
employing about 15,000 people in Africa.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
In Tanzania and Uganda,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
they represent 90 percent

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
of Coke's sales.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Let's look at the development side.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
What is it that governments and NGOs

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
can learn from Coke?

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Governments and NGOs

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
need to tap into that local entrepreneurial talent as well,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
because the locals know how to reach

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
the very hard-to-serve places, their neighbors,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and they know what motivates them to make change.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I think a great example of this

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
is Ethiopia's new health extension program.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
The government noticed in Ethiopia

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
that many of the people were so far away from a health clinic,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
they were over a day's travel away from a health clinic.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
So if you're in an emergency situation -- or if you're a mom about to deliver a baby --

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
forget it, to get to the health care center.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
They decided that wasn't good enough,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
so they went to India and studied the Indian state of Kerala

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
that also had a system like this,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and they adapted it for Ethiopia.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
And in 2003, the government of Ethiopia

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
started this new system in their own country.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
They trained 35,000 health extension workers

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
to deliver care directly to the people.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
In just five years,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
their ratio went from one worker for every 30,000 people

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
to one worker for every 2,500 people.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Now, think about

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
how this can change people's lives.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Health extension workers can help with so many things,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
whether it's family planning, prenatal care,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
immunizations for the children,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
or advising the woman to get to the facility on time

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
for an on-time delivery.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
That is having real impact

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
in a country like Ethiopia,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
and it's why you see their child mortality numbers

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
coming down 25 percent

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
from 2000 to 2008.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
In Ethiopia, there are hundreds of thousands of children living

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
because of this health extension worker program.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
So what's the next step for Ethiopia?

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Well, they're already starting talk about this.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
They're starting to talk about, "How do you have the health community workers

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
generate their own ideas?

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
How do you incent them based on the impact that they're getting

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
out in those remote villages?"

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
That's how you tap into local entrepreneurial talent

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and you unlock people's potential.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
The third component of Coke's success

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
is marketing.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Ultimately, Coke's success

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
depends on one crucial fact

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and that is that people want

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
a Coca-Cola.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Now the reason these micro-entrepreneurs

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
can sell or make a profit

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
is they have to sell every single bottle in their pushcart or their wheelbarrow.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
So, they rely on Coca-Cola

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
in terms of its marketing,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
and what's the secret to their marketing?

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Well, it's aspirational.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
It is associated that product

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
with a kind of life that people want to live.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
So even though it's a global company,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
they take a very local approach.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Coke's global campaign slogan

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
is "Open Happiness."

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
But they localize it.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And they don't just guess what makes people happy;

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
they go to places like Latin America

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and they realize that happiness there

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
is associated with family life.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And in South Africa,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
they associate happiness

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
with seriti or community respect.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Now, that played itself out in the World Cup campaign.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Let's listen to this song that Coke created for it,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
"Wavin' Flag" by a Somali hip hop artist.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
(Video) K'Naan: ♫ Oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
♫ Oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh ♫

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
♫ Oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
♫ Oh oh oh oh oh oh oh oh o-oh ♫

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
♫Give you freedom, give you fire♫

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
♫ Give you reason, take you higher ♫

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
♫ See the champions take the field now ♫

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
♫ You define us, make us feel proud ♫

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
♫ In the streets our heads are lifted ♫

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
♫ As we lose our inhibition ♫

♫ Celebration, it's around us ♫

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
♫ Every nation, all around us ♫

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Melinda French Gates: It feels pretty good, right?

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Well, they didn't stop there --

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
they localized it into 18 different languages.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
And it went number one on the pop chart

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
in 17 countries.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
It reminds me of a song that I remember from my childhood,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
"I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing,"

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
that also went number one on the pop charts.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Both songs have something in common:

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
that same appeal

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
of celebration and unity.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
So how does health and development market?

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Well, it's based on avoidance,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
not aspirations.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
I'm sure you've heard some of these messages.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
"Use a condom, don't get AIDS."

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
"Wash you hands, you might not get diarrhea."

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
It doesn't sound anything like "Wavin' Flag" to me.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
And I think we make a fundamental mistake --

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
we make an assumption,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
that we think that, if people need something,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
we don't have to make them want that.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
And I think that's a mistake.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
And there's some indications around the world that this is starting to change.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
One example is sanitation.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
We know that a million and a half children

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
die a year from diarrhea

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and a lot of it is because of open defecation.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
But there's a solution: you build a toilet.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
But what we're finding around the world, over and over again,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
is, if you build a toilet and you leave it there,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
it doesn't get used.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
People reuse it for a slab for their home.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
They sometimes store grain in it.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
I've even seen it used for a chicken coop.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
(Laughter)

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
But what does marketing really entail

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
that would make a sanitation solution get a result in diarrhea?

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Well, you work with the community.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
You start to talk to them about why open defecation

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
is something that shouldn't be done in the village,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and they agree to that.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
But then you take the toilet and you position it

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
as a modern, trendy convenience.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
One state in Northern India has gone so far

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
as to link toilets to courtship.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
And it works -- look at these headlines.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
(Laughter)

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
I'm not kidding.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Women are refusing to marry men without toilets.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
No loo, no "I do."

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
(Laughter)

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
Now, it's not just a funny headline --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
it's innovative. It's an innovative marketing campaign.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
But more importantly,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
it saves lives.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Take a look at this --

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
this is a room full of young men

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and my husband, Bill.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And can you guess what the young men are waiting for?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
They're waiting to be circumcised.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Can you you believe that?

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
We know that circumcision reduces HIV infection

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
by 60 percent in men.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
And when we first heard this result inside the Foundation,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
I have to admit, Bill and I were scratching our heads a little bit

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
and we were saying, "But who's going to volunteer for this procedure?"

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
But it turns out the men do,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
because they're hearing from their girlfriends

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
that they prefer it,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and the men also believe it improves their sex life.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
So if we can start to understand

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
what people really want

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
in health and development,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
we can change communities

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
and we can change whole nations.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Well, why is all of this so important?

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
So let's talk about what happens when this all comes together,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
when you tie the three things together.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And polio, I think, is one of the most powerful examples.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
We've seen a 99 percent reduction in polio in 20 years.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
So if you look back to 1988,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
there are about 350,000 cases of polio

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
on the planet that year.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
In 2009, we're down to 1,600 cases.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
Well how did that happen?

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
Let's look at a country like India.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
They have over a billion people in this country,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
but they have 35,000 local doctors

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
who report paralysis,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and clinicians, a huge reporting system in chemists.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
They have two and a half million vaccinators.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
But let me make the story a little bit more concrete for you.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
Let me tell you the story of Shriram,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
an 18 month boy in Bihar,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
a northern state in India.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
This year on August 8th, he felt paralysis

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and on the 13th, his parents took him to the doctor.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
On August 14th and 15th, they took a stool sample,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and by the 25th of August,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
it was confirmed he had Type 1 polio.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
By August 30th, a genetic test was done,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
and we knew what strain of polio Shriram had.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Now it could have come from one of two places.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
It could have come from Nepal, just to the north, across the border,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
or from Jharkhand, a state just to the south.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
Luckily, the genetic testing proved

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
that, in fact, this strand came north,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
because, had it come from the south,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
it would have had a much wider impact in terms of transmission.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
So many more people would have been affected.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So what's the endgame?

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Well on September 4th, there was a huge mop-up campaign,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
which is what you do in polio.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
They went out and where Shriram lives,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
they vaccinated two million people.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
So in less than a month,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
we went from one case of paralysis

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
to a targeted vaccination program.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And I'm happy to say only one other person in that area got polio.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
That's how you keep

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
a huge outbreak from spreading,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and it shows what can happen

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
when local people have the data in their hands;

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
they can save lives.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Now one of the challenges in polio, still, is marketing,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
but it might not be what you think.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
It's not the marketing on the ground.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
It's not telling the parents,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
"If you see paralysis, take your child to the doctor

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
or get your child vaccinated."

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
We have a problem with marketing in the donor community.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
The G8 nations have been incredibly generous on polio

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
over the last 20 years,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
but we're starting to have something called polio fatigue

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and that is that the donor nations

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
aren't willing to fund polio any longer.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
So by next summer, we're sighted to run out of money on polio.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
So we are 99 percent

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
of the way there on this goal

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
and we're about to run short of money.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And I think that if the marketing were more aspirational,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
if we could focus as a community

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
on how far we've come

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
and how amazing it would be

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
to eradicate this disease,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
we could put polio fatigue

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
and polio behind us.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And if we could do that,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
we could stop vaccinating everybody, worldwide,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
in all of our countries for polio.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
And it would only be the second disease ever

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
wiped off the face of the planet.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And we are so close.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
And this victory is so possible.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
So if Coke's marketers came to me

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and asked me to define happiness,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
I'd say my vision of happiness

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
is a mother holding healthy baby

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
in her arms.

title: Haiti's disaster of engineering
transcript: I learned about the Haiti earthquake by Skype. My wife sent me a message, "Whoa, earthquake," and then disappeared for 25 minutes. It was 25 minutes of absolute terror that thousands of people across the U.S. felt. I was afraid of a tsunami; what I didn't realize was there was a greater terror in Haiti, and that was building collapse. We've all seen the photos of the collapsed buildings in Haiti. These are shots my wife took a couple days after the quake, while I was making my way through the D.R. into the country. This is the national palace — the equivalent of the White House. This is the largest supermarket in the Caribbean at peak shopping time. This is a nurses' college — there are 300 nurses studying. The general hospital right next door emerged largely unscathed. This is the Ministry of Economics and Finance.We have all heard about the tremendous human loss in the earthquake in Haiti, but we haven't heard enough about why all those lives were lost. We haven't heard about why the buildings failed. After all, it was the buildings, not the earthquake, that killed 220,000 people, that injured 330,000, that displaced 1.3 million people, that cut off food and water and supplies for an entire nation. This is the largest metropolitan-area disaster in decades, and it was not a natural disaster — it was a disaster of engineering.AIDG has worked in Haiti since 2007, providing engineering and business support to small businesses. And after the quake, we started bringing in earthquake engineers to figure out why the buildings collapsed, to examine what was safe and what wasn't. Working with MINUSTAH, which is the U.N. mission in Haiti, with the Ministry of Public Works, with different NGOs, we inspected over 1,500 buildings. We inspected schools and private residencies. We inspected medical centers and food warehouses. We inspected government buildings.This is the Ministry of Justice. Behind that door is the National Judicial Archives. The fellow in the door, Andre Filitrault — who's the director of the Center for Interdisciplinary Earthquake Engineering Research at the University of Buffalo — was examining it to see if it was safe to recover the archives. Andre told me, after seeing these buildings fail again and again in the same way, that there is no new research here. There is nothing here that we don't know. The failure points were the same: walls and slabs not tied properly into columns — that's a roof slab hanging off the building — cantilevered structures, or structures that were asymmetric, that shook violently and came down, poor building materials, not enough concrete, not enough compression in the blocks, rebar that was smooth, rebar that was exposed to the weather and had rusted away.Now there's a solution to all these problems. And we know how to build properly. The proof of this came in Chile, almost a month later, when 8.8 magnitude earthquake hit Chile. That is 500 times the power of the 7.0 that hit Port-au-Prince — 500 times the power, yet only under a thousand casualties. Adjusted for population density, that is less than one percent of the impact of the Haitian quake. What was the difference between Chile and Haiti? Seismic standards and confined masonry, where the building acts as a whole — walls and columns and roofs and slabs tied together to support each other — instead of breaking off into separate members and failing. If you look at this building in Chile, it's ripped in half, but it's not a pile of rubble. Chileans have been building with confined masonry for decades.Right now, AIDG is working with KPFF Consulting Engineers, Architecture for Humanity, to bring more confined masonry training into Haiti. This is Xantus Daniel; he's a mason, just a general construction worker, not a foreman, who took one of our trainings. On his last job he was working with his boss, and they started pouring the columns wrong. He took his boss aside, and he showed him the materials on confined masonry. He showed him, "You know, we don't have to do this wrong. It won't cost us any more to do it the right way." And they redid that building. They tied the rebar right, they poured the columns right, and that building will be safe. And every building that they build going forward will be safe.To make sure these buildings are safe, it's not going to take policy — it's going to take reaching out to the masons on the ground and helping them learn the proper techniques. Now there are many groups doing this. And the fellow in the vest there, Craig Toten, he has pushed forward to get documentation out to all the groups that are doing this. Through Haiti Rewired, through Build Change, Architecture for Humanity, AIDG, there is the possibility to reach out to 30,000 — 40,000 masons across the country and create a movement of proper building. If you reach out to the people on the ground in this collaborative way it's extremely affordable. For the billions spent on reconstruction, you can train masons for dollars on every house that they end up building over their lifetime.Ultimately, there are two ways that you can rebuild Haiti; the way at the top is the way that Haiti's been building for decades. The way at the top is a poorly constructed building that will fail. The way at the bottom is a confined masonry building, where the walls are tied together, the building is symmetric, and it will stand up to an earthquake. For all the disaster, there is an opportunity here to build better houses for the next generation, so that when the next earthquake hits, it is a disaster — but not a tragedy.(Applause)
