title: The art of the eco-mindshift
transcript: I was informed by this kind of unoriginal and trite idea that new technologies were an opportunity for social transformation, which is what drove me then, and still, it's a delusion that drives me now. I wanted to update what I've been doing since then — but it's still the same theme song — and introduce you to my lab and current work, which is the Environmental Health Clinic that I run at NYU. And what it is — it's a twist on health. Because, really, what I'm trying to do now is redefine what counts as health. It's a clinic like a health clinic at any other university, except people come to the clinic with environmental health concerns, and they walk out with prescriptions for things they can do to improve environmental health, as opposed to coming to a clinic with medical concerns and walking out with prescriptions for pharmaceuticals.It's a handy-dandy quote from Hippocrates of the Hippocratic oath that says, "The greater part of the soul lays outside the body, treatment of the inner requires treatment of the outer." But that suggests the issue that I'm trying to get at here, that we have an opportunity to redefine what is health. Because this idea that health is internal and atomized and individual and pharmaceutical is largely an error. And I would use this study, a recent study by Philip Landrigan, to motivate a different view of health, where he went to most of the pediatricians in Manhattan and the New York area and logged what they spent their patient hours on. 80 to 90 percent of their time was spent on five things. Number one was asthma, number two was developmental delays, number three was 400-fold increases in rare childhood cancers in the last eight to 10, 15 years. Number four and five were childhood obesity and diabetes-related issues. So all of those — what's common about all of those? The environment is implicated, radically implicated, right. This is not the germs that medicos were trained to deal with; this is a different definition of health, health that has a great advantage because it's external, it's shared, we can do something about it, as opposed to internal, genetically predetermined or individualized.People who come to the clinic are called, not patients, but impatients, because they're too impatient to wait for legislative change to address local and environmental health issues. And I meet them at the University, I also have a few field offices that I set up in various places that provide an immersion in some of the environmental challenges we face. I like this one from the Belgian field office, where we met in a roundabout, precisely because the roundabout iconified the headless social movement that informs much social transformation, as opposed to the top-down control of red light traffic intersections. In this case, of course, the roundabout with that micro-decisions being made in situ by people not being told what to do. But, of course, affords greater throughput, fewer accidents, and an interesting model of social movement.Some of the things that the monitoring protocols have developed: this is the tadpole bureaucrat protocol, or keeping tabs, if you will. What they are is an addition of tadpoles that are named after a local bureaucrat whose decisions affect your water quality. So an impatient concerned for water quality would raise a tadpole bureaucrat in a sample of water in which they're interested. And we give them a couple of things to do that, to help them do companion animal devices while they're blogging and doing their email. This is a tadpole walker to take your tadpole walking in the evening. And the interesting thing that happens — because we're using tadpoles, of course, because they have the most exquisite biosenses that we have, several orders of magnitude more sensitive than some of our senses for sensing, responding in a biologically meaningful way, to that whole class of industrial contaminants we call endocrine disruptors or hormone emulators.But by taking your tadpole out for a walk in the evening — there's a few action shots — your neighbors are likely to say, "What are you doing?" And then you have to introduce your tadpole and who it's named after. You have to explain what you're doing and how the developmental events of a tadpole are, of course, very observable and they use the same T3-mediated hormones that we do. And so next time your neighbor sees you they'll say, "How is that tadpole doing?" And you can let them social network with your tadpole, because the Environmental Health Clinic has a social networking site for, not only impatients, humans, but non-humans, social networking for humans and non-humans. And of course, these endocrine disruptors are things that are implicated in the breast cancer epidemic, the obesity epidemic, the two and a half year drop in the average age of onset of puberty in young girls and other related things. The culmination of this is if you've successfully raised your tadpole, observing the behavioral and developmental events, you will then go and introduce your tadpole to its namesake and discuss the evidence that you've seen.Another quick protocol — and I'm going to go through these quickly, but just to give you the material sense of what we're doing here — instead of asking you for urine samples, I'll ask you for a mouse sample. Anyone here lucky enough to share, to cohabit with a mouse — a domestic partnership with mice? Very lucky. Mice, of course, are the quintessential model organism. They're even better models of environmental health, because not only the same mammalian biology, but they share your diet, largely. They share your environmental stressors, the asbestos levels and lead levels, whatever you're exposed to. And they're geographically more limited than you are, because we don't know if you've been exposed to persistent organic pollutants in your home, or occupationally or as a child. Mice are a very good representation. So it starts by building a better mousetrap, of course. This is one of them.Coping with environmental stressors is tricky. Is anybody here on antidepressants? (Laughter) There's a lot of people in Manhattan are. And we were testing if the mice would also self-administer SSRIs. So this was Prozac, this was Zoloft, this was a black jellybean and this was muscle relaxant, all of which were the medications that the impatient was taking. So do you think the mice self-administered antidepressants? What's the — (Audience: Sure. Yes.) How did you know that? They did. This was vodka and solution, gin and solution. This guy also liked plain water and the muscle relaxant. Where's our expert? Vodka, gin — (Audience: [unclear]) Yes. Yes. You know your mice well. They did, yes. So they drank as much vodka as they did plain water, which was interesting. Then of course, it goes into the entrapment device. There's an old cellphone in there — a good use for old cellphones — which dials the clinic, we go and pick up the mouse. We take the blood sample and do the blood work and hair work on the mice.And I want to sort of point out the big advantage of framing health in this external way. But we do have a few prescription products through this. It's very different from the medical model. Anything you do to improve your water quality or air quality, or to understand it or to change it, the benefits are enjoyed by anyone you share that water quality or air quality with. And that aggregating effect, that collective action effect, is actually something we can use to our advantage. So I want to show you one prescription product in the clinic called the No Park. This is a prescription to improve water quality. Many impatients are very concerned for water quality and air quality. What we do is we take a fire hydrant, a "no parking" space associated with a fire hydrant, and we prescribe the removal of the asphalt to create an engineered micro landscape, to create an infiltration opportunity.Because, many of you will know, that the biggest pollution burden that we have on the New York, New Jersey harbor right now is no longer the point sources, no longer the big polluters, no longer the GEs, but that massive network of roads, [those] impervious surfaces, that collect all that cadmium neurotoxin that comes from your brake liners or the oily hydrocarbon waste in every single storm event and medieval infrastructure washes it straight into the estuary system. That doesn't do a lot of good. These are little opportunities to intercept those pollutants before they enter the harbor, and they're produced by impatients on various city blocks in some very interesting ways. I just want to say it was sort of a rule of thumb though, there's about two or three fire hydrants on every city block. By creating engineered micro landscapes to infiltrate in them, we don't prevent them from being used as emergency vehicle parking spaces, because, of course, a firetruck can come and park there. They flatten a few plants. No big deal, they'll regenerate. But if we did this in every single — every fire hydrant we could redefine the emergency. That 99 percent of the time when a firetruck is not parking there, it's infiltrating pollutants. It's also increasing fixing CO2s, sequestering some of the airborne pollutants. And aggregated, these smaller interceptions could actually infiltrate all the roadborne pollution that now runs into the estuary system, up to a seven inch rain event, up to a hundred-year storm.So these are small actions that can amount to a significant effect to improve local environmental health. This is one of the more ambitious ones. What the climate crisis has revealed to us is a secondary, more insidious and more pervasive crisis, which is the crisis of agency, which is what to do. Somehow buying a local lettuce, changing a light bulb, driving the speed limit, changing your tires regularly, doesn't seem sufficient in the face of climate crisis. And this is an interesting icon that happened — you remember these: fallout shelters. What is the fallout shelter for the climate crisis? This was civic mobilization. Churches, school groups, hospitals, private residents — everyone built one of these in a matter of months. And they still remain as icons of civic response in the face of shared, uncertain, collective threat.Fallout shelter for the climate crisis, I would say, looks something like this, or this, which is an intensive urban agriculture facility that's due to go on my lab building at NYU. What it does is a very simple idea of taking — 80 to 90 percent of the CO2 produced in Manhattan is building related — we take, just like a commercial greenhouse, we take the CO2 from the building — CO2-enriched air — we force it through the urban agriculture facility, and then we resupply oxygen-enriched air. You can't actually build much on a roof, they're not designed for that. So it's on legs, so it focuses all the load on the masonry walls and the columns. It's built as a barn raising, using open source hardware. This is the quarter-scale prototype that was functioning in Spain. This is what it will look like, fingers crossed, NYU willing.And what I want to show you is — actually this is one of the components of it that we've just recently been testing — which is a solar chimney — we have got 17 of them now put around New York at the moment — that passively draws air up. You understand a solar chimney. Hot air rises. You put a bit of black plastic on the side of a building, it'll heat up, and you'll get passive airflow. What we do is actually put a standard HVAC filter on the top of that. That actually removes about 95 percent of the carbon black, that stuff that, with ozone, is responsible for about half of global warming's effects, because it changes, it settles on the snow, it changes the reflectors, it changes the transmission qualities of the atmosphere. Carbon black is that grime that otherwise lodges in your pretty pink lungs, and it's associated with. It's not good stuff, and it's from inefficient combustion, not from combustion itself. When we put it through our solar chimney, we remove actually about 95 percent of that. And then I swap it out with the students and actually re-release that carbon black. And we make pencils the length of which measures the grime that we've pulled out of the air. Here's one of them that we have up now. Here's who put them up and who are avid pencil users.Okay, so I want to show you just two more interfaces, because I think one of our big challenges is re-imagining our relationship to natural systems, not only through this model of twisted personalized health, but through the animals with whom we cohabit. We are not alone; the animals are moving in. In fact, urban migration now describes the movement of animals formerly known as wild into urban centers. You know, coyote in Central Park, a whale in the Gowanus Canal, elk in Westchester County. It's happening all over the Developed World, probably for loss of habitat, but also because our cities are a little bit more livable than they have been. And every green space we create is an invitation for non-humans to cohabit with us. But we've kind of lacked imagination in how we could do that well or interestingly. And I want to show you a few of the technological interfaces that have been developed under the moniker of OOZ — which is zoo backwards and without cages — to try and reform that relationship. This is communication technology for birds. It looks like this. When a bird lands on it, they trigger a sound file. This is actually in the Whitney Museum, where there were six of them, each of which had a different argument on it, different sound file. They said things like this.(Whistling)Recorded Voice: Here's what you need to do. Go down there and buy some of those health food bars, the ones you call bird food, and bring it here and scatter it around. There's a good person.Natalie Jeremijenko: Okay. (Laugher) So there was several of these. The birds were able to jump from one to the other. These are just your average urban pigeon. And an early test which argument elicited cooperative behavior from the people below — about a hundred to one decided that this was the argument that worked best on us.Recorded Voice: Tick, tick, tick. That's the sound of genetic mutations of the avian flu becoming a deadly human flu. Do you know what slows it down? Healthy sub-populations of birds, increasing biodiversity generally. It is in your interests that I'm healthy, happy, well-fed. Hence, you could share some of your nutritional resources instead of monopolizing them. That is, share your lunch.(Laughter)NJ: It worked, and it's true. The final project I'd like to show you is a new interface for fish that has just been launched — it's actually officially launched next week — with a wonderful commission from the Architectural League. You may not have known that you need to communicate with fish, but there is now a device for you to do so. It looks like this: buoys that float on the water, project three foot up, three foot down. When a fish swims underneath, a light goes on. This is what it looks like. So there's another function on here. This top light is — I'm sorry if I'm making you seasick — this top light is actually a water quality display that shifts from red, when the dissolved oxygen is low, to a blue/green, when its dissolved oxygen is high. And then you can also text the fish. So there's business cards down there that'll give you contact details. And they text back. When the buoys get your text, they wink at you twice to say, we've got your message. But perhaps the most popular has been that we've got another array of these boys in the Bronx River, where the first beaver — crazy as he is — to have moved in and built a lodge in New York in 250 years, hangs out. So updates from a beaver. You can subscribe to updates from him. You can talk to him.And what I like to think of is this is an interface that re-scripts how we interact with natural systems, specifically by changing who has information, where they have it, who can make sense of that information, and what you can do about it. In this case, instead of throwing chewing gum, or Doritos or whatever you have in your pocket at the fish — There's a body of water in Iceland that I've been dealing with that's in the middle of the city, and the largest pollution burden on it is not the roadborne pollution, it's actually white bread from people feeding the fish and the birds. Instead of doing that actually, we've developed some fish sticks that you can feed the fish. They're delicious. They're cross-species delicious that is, delicious for humans and non-humans. But they also have a chelating agent in them. They're nutritionally appropriate, not like Doritos. And so every time that desire to interact with the animals, which is at least as ubiquitous as that sign: "Do not feed the animals." And there's about three of them on every New York City park. And Yellowstone National Park, there's more "do not feed the animals" signs than there are animals you might wish to feed. But in that action, that interaction, by re-scripting that, by changing it into an opportunity to offer food that is nutritionally appropriate, that could augment the nutritional resources that we ourselves have depleted for augmenting the fish population and also adding chelating agent, which, like any chelating agent that we use medicinally, binds to the bioaccumulated heavy metals and PCBs that are in the fish living in this particular habitat and allows them to pass it out as a harmless salt where it's complexed by a reactive, effectively removing it from bioavailability.But I wanted to say that interaction, re-scripting that interaction, into collective action, collective remediative action, very different from the approach that's being used on the other side on the Hudson River, where we're dredging the PCBs — after 30 years of legislative and legal struggle, GE's paying for the dredging of the largest Superfund site in the world — we're dredging it, and it'll probably get shipped off to Pennsylvania or the nearest Third World country, where it will continue to be toxic sludge. Displacement is not the way to deal with environmental issues. And that's typically the paradigm under which we've operated.By actually taking the opportunity that new technologies, new interactive technologies, present to re-script our interactions, to script them, not just as isolated, individuated interactions, but as collective aggregating actions that can amount to something, we can really begin to address some of our important environmental challenges.Thank you.(Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I was informed by this kind of

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
unoriginal and trite idea

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
that new technologies were an opportunity

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
for social transformation,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
which is what drove me then,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
and still, it's a delusion that drives me now.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
I wanted to update what I've been doing since then --

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
but it's still the same theme song --

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
and introduce you to my lab and current work,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
which is the Environmental Health Clinic

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
that I run at NYU.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
And what it is -- it's a twist on health.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Because, really, what I'm trying to do now

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
is redefine what counts as health.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
It's a clinic like a health clinic at any other university,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
except people come to the clinic

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
with environmental health concerns,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
and they walk out with prescriptions

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
for things they can do to improve environmental health,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
as opposed to coming to a clinic with medical concerns

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and walking out with prescriptions for pharmaceuticals.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
It's a handy-dandy quote from Hippocrates of the Hippocratic oath

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
that says, "The greater part of the soul lays outside the body,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
treatment of the inner requires treatment of the outer."

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
But that suggests the issue

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
that I'm trying to get at here,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
that we have an opportunity to redefine what is health.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
Because this idea that health is internal

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
and atomized and individual

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:23.958
and pharmaceutical

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
is largely an error.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And I would use this study,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
a recent study by Philip Landrigan,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
to motivate a different view of health,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
where he went to most of the pediatricians in Manhattan

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and the New York area

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
and logged what they spent their patient hours on.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
80 to 90 percent of their time

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
was spent on five things.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
Number one was asthma,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
number two was developmental delays,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
number three was 400-fold increases

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
in rare childhood cancers

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
in the last eight to 10, 15 years.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
Number four and five were childhood obesity

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
and diabetes-related issues.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
So all of those -- what's common about all of those?

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
The environment is implicated, radically implicated, right.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
This is not the germs

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
that medicos were trained to deal with;

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
this is a different definition of health,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
health that has a great advantage

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
because it's external, it's shared,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
we can do something about it,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
as opposed to internal, genetically predetermined

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
or individualized.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
People who come to the clinic are called, not patients,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
but impatients,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
because they're too impatient to wait for legislative change

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
to address local and environmental health issues.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And I meet them at the University, I also have a few field offices

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
that I set up in various places

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
that provide an immersion

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
in some of the environmental challenges we face.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
I like this one from the Belgian field office,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
where we met in a roundabout,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
precisely because the roundabout iconified

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
the headless social movement

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
that informs much social transformation,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
as opposed to the top-down control

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
of red light traffic intersections.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
In this case, of course, the roundabout

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
with that micro-decisions being made in situ

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
by people not being told what to do.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
But, of course, affords greater throughput,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
fewer accidents,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
and an interesting model of social movement.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Some of the things that the monitoring protocols have developed:

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
this is the tadpole bureaucrat protocol,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
or keeping tabs, if you will.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
What they are is an addition of tadpoles

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
that are named after a local bureaucrat

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
whose decisions affect your water quality.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
So an impatient concerned for water quality

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
would raise a tadpole bureaucrat

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
in a sample of water in which they're interested.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
And we give them a couple of things to do that,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
to help them do companion animal devices

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
while they're blogging and doing their email.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
This is a tadpole walker

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
to take your tadpole walking in the evening.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And the interesting thing that happens --

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
because we're using tadpoles, of course,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
because they have the most exquisite biosenses that we have,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
several orders of magnitude more sensitive

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
than some of our senses

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
for sensing,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
responding in a biologically meaningful way,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
to that whole class of industrial contaminants

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
we call endocrine disruptors

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
or hormone emulators.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
But by taking your tadpole out for a walk in the evening --

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
there's a few action shots --

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
your neighbors are likely to say, "What are you doing?"

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And then you have to introduce your tadpole

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
and who it's named after.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
You have to explain what you're doing

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
and how the developmental events of a tadpole

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
are, of course, very observable

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and they use the same T3-mediated hormones that we do.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
And so next time your neighbor sees you

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
they'll say, "How is that tadpole doing?"

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
And you can let them social network with your tadpole,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
because the Environmental Health Clinic has a social networking site

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
for, not only impatients, humans,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
but non-humans,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
social networking for humans and non-humans.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And of course, these endocrine disruptors

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
are things that are implicated in the breast cancer epidemic,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
the obesity epidemic,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
the two and a half year drop in the average age of onset of puberty in young girls

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
and other related things.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
The culmination of this is if you've successfully raised your tadpole,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
observing the behavioral

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
and developmental events,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
you will then go and introduce your tadpole

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
to its namesake

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
and discuss the evidence that you've seen.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Another quick protocol -- and I'm going to go through these quickly,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
but just to give you the material sense of what we're doing here --

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
instead of asking you for urine samples,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
I'll ask you for a mouse sample.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Anyone here lucky enough to share, to cohabit with a mouse --

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
a domestic partnership with mice?

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Very lucky.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Mice, of course, are the quintessential

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
model organism.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
They're even better models of environmental health,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
because not only the same mammalian biology,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
but they share your diet, largely.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
They share your environmental stressors,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
the asbestos levels and lead levels,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
whatever you're exposed to.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
And they're geographically more limited than you are,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
because we don't know if you've been exposed

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
to persistent organic pollutants

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
in your home, or occupationally

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
or as a child.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Mice are a very good representation.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
So it starts by building a better mousetrap, of course.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
This is one of them.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Coping with environmental stressors is tricky.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Is anybody here on antidepressants?

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
(Laughter)

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
There's a lot of people in Manhattan are.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And we were testing if the mice

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
would also self-administer SSRIs.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
So this was Prozac, this was Zoloft,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
this was a black jellybean and this was muscle relaxant,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
all of which were the medications that the impatient was taking.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
So do you think the mice

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
self-administered antidepressants?

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
What's the -- (Audience: Sure. Yes.)

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
How did you know that? They did.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
This was vodka and solution, gin and solution.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
This guy also liked plain water and the muscle relaxant.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Where's our expert?

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Vodka, gin --

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
(Audience: [unclear])

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Yes. Yes. You know your mice well.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
They did, yes.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
So they drank as much vodka as they did plain water,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
which was interesting.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
Then of course, it goes into the entrapment device.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
There's an old cellphone in there -- a good use for old cellphones --

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
which dials the clinic, we go and pick up the mouse.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
We take the blood sample

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and do the blood work and hair work on the mice.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
And I want to sort of point out the big advantage

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
of framing health in this external way.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
But we do have a few prescription products through this.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
It's very different from the medical model.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Anything you do to improve your water quality or air quality,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
or to understand it or to change it,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
the benefits are enjoyed by anyone

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
you share that water quality or air quality with.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And that aggregating effect,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
that collective action effect,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
is actually something we can use to our advantage.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
So I want to show you one prescription product in the clinic

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
called the No Park.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
This is a prescription to improve water quality.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Many impatients are very concerned for water quality and air quality.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
What we do is we take a fire hydrant,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
a "no parking" space associated with a fire hydrant,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and we prescribe the removal of the asphalt

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
to create an engineered micro landscape,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
to create an infiltration opportunity.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Because, many of you will know,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
that the biggest pollution burden

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
that we have on the New York, New Jersey harbor right now

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
is no longer the point sources,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
no longer the big polluters,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
no longer the GEs,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
but that massive network of roads,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
[those] impervious surfaces,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
that collect all that cadmium neurotoxin that comes from your brake liners

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
or the oily hydrocarbon waste

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
in every single storm event and medieval infrastructure

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
washes it straight into the estuary system.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
That doesn't do a lot of good.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
These are little opportunities to intercept those pollutants

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
before they enter the harbor,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and they're produced by impatients

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
on various city blocks

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
in some very interesting ways.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
I just want to say it was sort of a rule of thumb though,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
there's about two or three fire hydrants

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
on every city block.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
By creating engineered micro landscapes to infiltrate in them,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
we don't prevent them from being used

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
as emergency vehicle parking spaces,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
because, of course, a firetruck can come and park there.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
They flatten a few plants. No big deal, they'll regenerate.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
But if we did this

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
in every single --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
every fire hydrant

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
we could redefine the emergency.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
That 99 percent of the time

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
when a firetruck is not parking there,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
it's infiltrating pollutants.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
It's also increasing fixing CO2s,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
sequestering some of the airborne pollutants.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And aggregated,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
these smaller interceptions

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
could actually infiltrate all the roadborne pollution

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
that now runs into the estuary system,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
up to a seven inch rain event, up to a hundred-year storm.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So these are small actions

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
that can amount to a significant effect

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
to improve local environmental health.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
This is one of the more ambitious ones.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
What the climate crisis has revealed to us

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
is a secondary, more insidious

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and more pervasive crisis,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
which is the crisis of agency,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
which is what to do.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Somehow buying a local lettuce, changing a light bulb,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
driving the speed limit, changing your tires regularly,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
doesn't seem sufficient

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
in the face of climate crisis.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And this is an interesting icon that happened --

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
you remember these: fallout shelters.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
What is the fallout shelter

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
for the climate crisis?

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
This was civic mobilization.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Churches, school groups,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
hospitals, private residents --

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
everyone built one of these in a matter of months.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
And they still remain

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
as icons of civic response

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
in the face of shared, uncertain, collective threat.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Fallout shelter for the climate crisis,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
I would say, looks something like this, or this,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
which is an intensive urban agriculture facility

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
that's due to go on my lab building at NYU.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
What it does

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
is a very simple idea

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
of taking --

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
80 to 90 percent of the CO2 produced in Manhattan

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
is building related --

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
we take, just like a commercial greenhouse,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
we take the CO2 from the building --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
CO2-enriched air --

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
we force it through the urban agriculture facility,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and then we resupply oxygen-enriched air.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
You can't actually build much on a roof, they're not designed for that.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
So it's on legs,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
so it focuses all the load on the masonry walls and the columns.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
It's built as a barn raising,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
using open source hardware.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
This is the quarter-scale prototype

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
that was functioning in Spain.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
This is what it will look like, fingers crossed,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
NYU willing.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And what I want to show you is --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
actually this is one of the components of it that we've just recently been testing --

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
which is a solar chimney --

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
we have got 17 of them now put around New York at the moment --

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
that passively draws air up.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
You understand a solar chimney.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Hot air rises.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
You put a bit of black plastic on the side of a building,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
it'll heat up, and you'll get passive airflow.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
What we do is actually

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
put a standard HVAC filter on the top of that.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
That actually removes about 95 percent

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
of the carbon black,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
that stuff that, with ozone,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
is responsible for about half of global warming's effects,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
because it changes, it settles on the snow,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
it changes the reflectors,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
it changes

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
the transmission qualities of the atmosphere.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Carbon black is that grime

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
that otherwise lodges in your pretty pink lungs,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
and it's associated with.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
It's not good stuff, and it's from inefficient combustion,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
not from combustion itself.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
When we put it through our solar chimney,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
we remove actually about 95 percent of that.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And then I swap it out

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
with the students

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
and actually re-release that carbon black.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And we make pencils the length of which measures the grime

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
that we've pulled out of the air.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Here's one of them that we have up now.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Here's who put them up and who are avid pencil users.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Okay, so I want to show you

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
just two more interfaces,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
because I think one of our big challenges

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
is re-imagining our relationship to natural systems,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
not only through this model

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
of twisted personalized health,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
but through the animals

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
with whom we cohabit.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
We are not alone; the animals are moving in.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
In fact, urban migration now describes

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
the movement of animals formerly known as wild

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
into urban centers.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
You know, coyote in Central Park, a whale in the Gowanus Canal,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
elk in Westchester County.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
It's happening all over the Developed World,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
probably for loss of habitat,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
but also because our cities are a little bit more livable

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
than they have been.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And every green space we create

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
is an invitation for non-humans to cohabit with us.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
But we've kind of lacked imagination

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
in how we could do that well or interestingly.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
And I want to show you a few of the technological interfaces

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
that have been developed under the moniker of OOZ --

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
which is zoo backwards and without cages --

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
to try and reform

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
that relationship.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
This is communication technology for birds. It looks like this.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
When a bird lands on it, they trigger a sound file.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
This is actually in the Whitney Museum, where there were six of them,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
each of which had a different argument on it,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
different sound file.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
They said things like this.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
(Whistling)

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
Recorded Voice: Here's what you need to do.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Go down there and buy some of those health food bars,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
the ones you call bird food,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
and bring it here and scatter it around.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
There's a good person.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Natalie Jeremijenko: Okay. (Laugher)

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
So there was several of these.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
The birds were able to jump from one to the other.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
These are just your average urban pigeon.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
And an early test

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
which argument elicited cooperative behavior

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
from the people below --

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
about a hundred to one

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
decided that this was the argument

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
that worked best on us.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Recorded Voice: Tick, tick, tick.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
That's the sound of genetic mutations

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
of the avian flu

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
becoming a deadly human flu.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Do you know what slows it down?

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
Healthy sub-populations of birds,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
increasing biodiversity generally.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
It is in your interests that I'm healthy,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
happy, well-fed.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Hence, you could share some of your nutritional resources

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
instead of monopolizing them.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
That is, share your lunch.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
(Laughter)

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
NJ: It worked, and it's true.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
The final project I'd like to show you

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
is a new interface for fish

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
that has just been launched --

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
it's actually officially launched next week --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
with a wonderful commission from the Architectural League.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
You may not have known that you need to communicate with fish,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
but there is now a device for you to do so.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
It looks like this: buoys that float on the water,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
project three foot up, three foot down.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
When a fish swims underneath, a light goes on.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
This is what it looks like.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So there's another function on here.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
This top light is -- I'm sorry if I'm making you seasick --

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
this top light is actually a water quality display

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
that shifts from red, when the dissolved oxygen is low,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
to a blue/green, when its dissolved oxygen is high.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And then you can also text the fish.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
So there's business cards down there

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
that'll give you contact details.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
And they text back.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
When the buoys get your text, they wink at you twice to say, we've got your message.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
But perhaps the most popular has been

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
that we've got another array of these boys in the Bronx River,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
where the first beaver --

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
crazy as he is --

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
to have moved in and built a lodge in New York

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
in 250 years, hangs out.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
So updates from a beaver.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
You can subscribe to updates from him. You can talk to him.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
And what I like to think of

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
is this is an interface

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
that re-scripts how we interact with natural systems,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
specifically by changing who has information,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
where they have it,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
who can make sense of that information,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
and what you can do about it.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
In this case, instead of throwing chewing gum,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
or Doritos or whatever you have in your pocket at the fish --

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
There's a body of water in Iceland that I've been dealing with

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
that's in the middle of the city,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
and the largest pollution burden on it

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
is not the roadborne pollution,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
it's actually white bread

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
from people feeding the fish and the birds.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Instead of doing that actually, we've developed some fish sticks

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
that you can feed the fish.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
They're delicious.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
They're cross-species delicious that is,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
delicious for humans and non-humans.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
But they also have a chelating agent in them.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
They're nutritionally appropriate,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
not like Doritos.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
And so every time

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
that desire to interact with the animals,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:42.958
which is at least as ubiquitous

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
as that sign: "Do not feed the animals."

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
And there's about three of them on every New York City park.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And Yellowstone National Park,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
there's more "do not feed the animals" signs

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
than there are animals you might wish to feed.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
But in that action, that interaction,

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
by re-scripting that,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
by changing it into an opportunity

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
to offer food that is nutritionally appropriate,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
that could augment the nutritional resources

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
that we ourselves have depleted

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
for augmenting the fish population

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
and also adding chelating agent,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:16.958
which, like any chelating agent that we use medicinally,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
binds to the bioaccumulated heavy metals and PCBs

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
that are in the fish

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
living in this particular habitat

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
and allows them to pass it out as a harmless salt

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
where it's complexed by a reactive,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.958
effectively removing it from bioavailability.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
But I wanted to say that interaction,

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:36.958
re-scripting that interaction,

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
into collective action, collective remediative action,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
very different from the approach

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
that's being used on the other side on the Hudson River,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
where we're dredging the PCBs --

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
after 30 years of legislative and legal struggle,

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
GE's paying for the dredging

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
of the largest Superfund site in the world --

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.958
we're dredging it, and it'll probably get shipped off to Pennsylvania

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
or the nearest Third World country,

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
where it will continue to be toxic sludge.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Displacement is not the way to deal with environmental issues.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
And that's typically the paradigm

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
under which we've operated.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
By actually taking the opportunity

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
that new technologies,

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:20.958
new interactive technologies, present

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
to re-script our interactions,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
to script them,

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
not just as isolated, individuated interactions,

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
but as collective aggregating actions

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
that can amount to something,

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
we can really begin to address

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
some of our important environmental challenges.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
Thank you.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
(Applause)

title: My web playroom
transcript: Every presentation needs this slide in it. (Laughter) It's beautiful, isn't it? Do you see? All the points, all the lines — it's incredible. It is the network; and in my case, the network has been important in media, because I get to connect to people. Isn't it amazing? Through that, I connect to people. And the way that I've been doing it has been multifaceted. For example, I get people to dress up their vacuum cleaners. (Laughter) I put together projects like Earth Sandwich, where I ask people to try and simultaneously place two pieces of bread perfectly opposite each other on the Earth. And people started laying bread in tribute, and eventually a team was able to do it between New Zealand and Spain. It's pretty incredible — the video's online. Connecting to people in projects like YoungmeNowme for example. In YoungmeNowme, the audience was asked to find a childhood photograph of themselves and restage it as an adult. (Laughter) This is the same person — top photo, James, bottom photo, [Jennifer]. Poignant. This was a Mother's Day gift. (Laughter) Particularly creepy. (Applause) (Laughter) My favorite of these photos, which I couldn't find, is there's a picture of a 30 year-old woman or so with a little baby on her lap, and the next photo is a 220-lb man with a tiny, little old lady peaking over his shoulder.But this project changed the way that I thought about connecting to people. This is project called Ray. And what happened was I was sent this piece of audio and had no idea who generated the audio. Somebody said, "You have to listen to this." And this is what came to me.Recording: Hi, my name is Ray, and on yesterday my daughter called me because she was stressed out because of things that were going on on her job that she felt was quite unfair. Being quite disturbed, she called for comfort, and I didn't really know what to tell her, because we have to deal with so much mess in our society. So I was led to write this song just for her, just to give her some encouragement while dealing with stress and pressures on her job. And I figured I'd put it on the Internet for all employees under stress to help you better deal with what you're going through on your job. Here's how the song goes.♫ I'm about to whip somebody's ass ♫♫ Oh, I'm about to whip somebody's ass ♫♫ Oh, if you don't leave me alone, ♫♫ you gonna have to send me home ♫♫ 'Cause I'm about to whip somebody's ass ♫Now you might not be able to sing that out loud, but you can hum it to yourself, and you know what the words are. And let it give you some strength to get the next few moments on your job. All right. Stay strong. Peace.Ze Frank: So — yeah. No, no, no, shush. We've got to go quickly. So I was so moved by this — this is incredible. This was connecting, right. This was, at a distance, realizing that someone was feeling something, wanting to affect them in a particular way, using media to do it, putting it online and realizing that there was a greater impact. He's got a great voice. It's actually in the key of B flat. And have to do something with it." Hundreds of remixes came back — lots of different attempts. One stood out in particular. That song — (Applause) Thank you. So that song, somebody told me that it was at a baseball game in Kansas City. In the end, it was one of the top downloads on a whole bunch of music streaming services. And so I said, "Let's put this together in an album." And I collected those moments — the photos inside Google Streetview and the memories, specifically. Right after September 11th, last year, I was thinking about pain and the way that we disperse it, the way that we excise it from our bodies. So what I did is I opened up a hotline — a hotline where people could leave voicemails of their pain, not necessarily related to that event. he was going to be separating from my mom,

I remember walking to a convenience store

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
and getting a cherry cola."

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
"They used some of the morbidly artist footage,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
a close-up of Chad's shoes in the middle of the highway.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
I guess the shoes came off when he was hit.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
He slept over at my house once, and he left his pillow.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
It had 'Chad' written in magic marker on it.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
He died long after he left the pillow at my house,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
but we never got around to returning it."

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
Sometimes they're a little bit more abstract.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
This is Pain Pack.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
Right after September 11th, last year,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
I was thinking about pain and the way that we disperse it,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
the way that we excise it from our bodies.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
So what I did is I opened up a hotline --

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
a hotline where people could leave voicemails of their pain,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
not necessarily related to that event.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And people called in and left messages like this.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
Recording: Okay, here's something.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
I'm not alone,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and I am loved.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
I'm really fortunate.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
But sometimes I feel really lonely.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And when I feel that way

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
even the smallest act of kindness

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
can make me cry.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Like even people in convenience stores

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
saying, "Have a nice day,"

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
when they're accidentally looking me in the eye.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
ZF: So what I did was I took those voicemails,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and with their permission, converted them to MP3s

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and distributed them to sound editors

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
who created short sounds

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
using just those voicemails.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And those were then distributed to DJs

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
who have made hundreds of songs

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
using that source material.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
(Music)

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We don't have time to play much of it.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
You can look at it online.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
"From 52 to 48 with love"

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
was a project around the time of the last election cycle,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
where McCain and Obama both,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
in their speeches after the election, talked about reconciliation,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
and I was like, "What the hell

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
does that look like?"

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
So I thought, "Well let's just give it a try.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Let's have people hold up signs about reconciliation."

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
And so some really nice things came together.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
"I voted blue. I voted red.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Together, for our future."

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
These are very, very cute little things right.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Some came from the winning party.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
"Dear 48, I promise to listen to you, to fight for you, to respect you always."

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Some came from the party who had just lost.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
"From a 48 to a 52, may your party's leadership be as classy as you,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
but I doubt it."

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
But the truth was that as this start becoming popular,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
a couple rightwing blogs and some message boards

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
apparently found it to be a little patronizing,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
which I could also see.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And so I started getting amazing amounts of hate mail,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
death threats even.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And one guy in particular kept on writing me these pretty awful messages,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and he was dressed as Batman.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And he said, "I'm dressed as Batman to hide my identity."

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
Just in case I thought the real Batman

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
was coming after me;

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
which actually made me feel a little better --

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
like, "Phew, it's not him."

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
So what I did --

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
unfortunately, I was harboring all this kind of

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
awful experience and this pain inside of me,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and it started to eat away at my psyche.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And I was protecting the project from it, I realized. I was protecting it --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
I didn't want this special, little group of photographs

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
to get sullied in some way.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
So what I did, I took all those emails,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and I put them together into something called Angrigami,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
which was an origami template

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
made out of this sort of vile stuff.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And I asked people to send me beautiful things

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
made out of the Angrigami.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:56.958
(Laughter)

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
But this was the emotional moment.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
One of my viewer's uncles died on a particular day

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
and he chose to commemorate it with a piece of hate.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
It's amazing.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
The last thing I'm going to tell you about is a series of projects

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
called Songs You Already Know,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
where the idea was,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
I was trying to figure out to address

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
particular kinds of emotions with group projects.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
So one of them was fairly straightforward.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
A guy said that his daughter got scared at night

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
and could I write a song for her, his daughter.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And I said, "Oh yeah,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
I'll try to write a mantra that she can sing to herself

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
to help herself go to sleep."

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And this was "Scared."

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
(Video) ♫ This is a song that I sing when I'm scared of something ♫

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
♫ I don't know why but it helps me get over it ♫

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
♫ The words of the song just move me along ♫

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
♫ And somehow I get over it ♫

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
♫ At least I don't suck at life ♫

♫ I keep on trying despite ♫

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
♫ At least I don't suck at life ♫

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
♫ I keep on trying despite ♫

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
♫ This is a song that I sing when I'm scared of something ♫

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Okay, so I wrote that song, right. Thank you.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
So the nice thing was is he walked by his daughter's room at some point,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and she actually was singing that song to herself.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
So I was like, "Awesome. This is great."

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And then I got this email. And there's a little bit of a back story to this.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And I don't have much time.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
But the idea was that at one point

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
I did a project called Facebook Me Equals You,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
where I wanted to experience what it was like

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
to live as another person.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So I asked for people's usernames and passwords to be sent to me.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
And I got a lot, like 30 in a half an hour.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And I shut that part down.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And I chose two people to be,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and I asked them to send me descriptions

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
of how to act as them on Facebook.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
One person sent me a very detailed description;

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
the other person didn't.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And the person who didn't, it turned out,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
had just moved to a new city and taken on a new job.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
So, you know, people were writing me and saying, "How's your new job?"

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
I was like, "I don't know.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
Didn't know I had one."

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
But anyway, this same person, Laura,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
ended up emailing me a little bit after that project.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And I felt badly for not having done a good job.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And she said, "I'm really anxious, I just moved to a new town, I have this new job,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
and I've just had this incredible amount of anxiety."

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
So she had seen the "Scared" song and wondered if I could do something.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
So I asked her, "What does it feel like when you feel this way?"

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And she wrote a sort of descriptive set

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
of what it felt like to have had this anxiety.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And so what I decided to do.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
I said, "Okay, I'll think about it."

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
And so quietly in the background, I started sending people this.

So I asked people

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
whether they had basic audio capabilities,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
just so they could sing along to the song with headphones on,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
so I could just get their voices back.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
And this is the kind of thing that I got back.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
ZF: So that's one of the better ones, really.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
But what's awesome is, as I started getting more and more and more of them,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
all of a sudden I had 30, 40 voices from around the world.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
And when you put them together, something magical happens,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
something absolutely incredible happens,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
and all of a sudden I get a chorus from around the world.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
And what was really great is, I'm putting all this work together in the background,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
