00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
But think of what it does

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
to how we think in traditional terms and concepts.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
We think in terms of war

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
and interstate war.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
And you can think back to 1941

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
when the government of Japan

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
attacked the United States at Pearl Harbor.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
It's worth noticing

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
that a non-state actor

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
attacking the United States in 2001

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
killed more Americans

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
than the government of Japan did in 1941.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
You might think of that

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
as the privatization of war.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
So we're seeing a great change

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
in terms of diffusion of power.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
Now the problem is

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
that we're not thinking about it in very innovative ways.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
So let me step back

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and ask: what's power?

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Power is simple the ability

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
to affect others

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
to get the outcomes you want,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
and you can do it in three ways.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
You can do it with threats

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
of coercion, "sticks,"

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
you can do it with payments,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
"carrots,"

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
or you can do it by getting others

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
to want what you want.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And that ability to get others to want what you want,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
to get the outcomes you want

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
without coercion or payment,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
is what I call soft power.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
And that soft power has been much neglected

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
and much misunderstood,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
and yet it's tremendously important.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
Indeed, if you can learn

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
to use more soft power,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
you can save a lot

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
on carrots and sticks.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Traditionally, the way people thought about power

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
was primarily in terms of military power.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
For example, the great Oxford historian

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
who taught here at this university, A.J.P. Taylor,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
defined a great power

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
as a country able to prevail in war.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
But we need a new narrative

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
if we're to understand power in the 21st century.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
It's not just prevailing at war,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
though war still persists.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
It's not whose army wins;

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
it's also whose story wins.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And we have to think much more in terms of narratives

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
and whose narrative is going to be effective.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Now let me go back

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
to the question

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
of power transition

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
between states

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
and what's happening there.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
the narratives that we use now

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
tend to be the rise and fall

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
of the great powers.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And the current narrative is all about

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
the rise of China

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and the decline of the United States.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Indeed, with the 2008 financial crisis,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
many people said this was

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
the beginning of the end of American power.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
The tectonic plates

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
of world politics were shifting.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And president Medvedev of Russia, for example,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
pronounced in 2008

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
this was the beginning of the end

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
of United States power.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
But in fact,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
this metaphor of decline

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
is often very misleading.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
If you look at history, in recent history,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
you'll see the cycles of belief

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
in American decline

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
come and go every 10 or 15 years or so.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
In 1958,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
after the Soviets put up Sputnik,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
it was "That's the end of America."

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
In 1973, with the oil embargo

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and the closing of the gold window,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
that was the end of America.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
In the 1980s,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
as America went through a transition in the Reagan period,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
between the rust belt economy of the midwest

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
to the Silicon Valley economy of California,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
that was the end of America.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
But in fact, what we've seen

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
is none of those were true.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
Indeed, people were over-enthusiastic

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
in the early 2000s,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
thinking America could do anything,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
which led us into some disastrous

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
foreign policy adventures,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and now we're back to decline again.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
The moral of this story

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
is all these narratives about rise and fall and decline

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
tell us a lot more about psychology

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
than they do about reality.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
If we try to focus on the reality,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
then what we need to focus on

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
is what's really happening

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
in terms of China and the United States.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Goldman Sachs has projected

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
that China, the Chinese economy,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
will surpass that of the U.S.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
by 2027.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
So we've got, what,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
17 more years to go or so

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
before China's bigger.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
Now someday,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
with a billion point three people getting richer,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
they are going to be bigger than the United States.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
But be very careful about these projections

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
such as the Goldman Sachs projection

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
as though that gives you an accurate picture

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
of power transition in this century.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
Let me mention three reasons why it's too simple.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
First of all, it's a linear projection.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
You know, everything says,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
here's the growth rate of China, here's the growth rate of the U.S.,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
here it goes -- straight line.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
History is not linear.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
There are often bumps along the road, accidents along the way.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
The second thing is

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
that the Chinese economy

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
passes the U.S. economy in, let's say, 2030,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
which it may it,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
that will be a measure of total economic size,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
but not of per capita income --

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
won't tell you about the composition of the economy.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
China still has large areas

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
of underdevelopment

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and per capita income is a better measure

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
of the sophistication of the economy.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And that the Chinese won't catch up or pass the Americans

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
until somewhere in the latter part,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
after 2050, of this century.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
The other point that's worth noticing

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
is how one-dimensional

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
this projection is.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
You know, it looks at economic power

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
measured by GDP.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Doesn't tell you much about military power,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
doesn't tell you very much about soft power.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
It's all very one-dimensional.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
And also, when we think about the rise of Asia,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
or return of Asia

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
as I called it a little bit earlier,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
it's worth remembering Asia's not one thing.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
If you're sitting in Japan,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
or in New Delhi,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
or in Hanoi,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
your view of the rise of China

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
is a little different than if you're sitting in Beijing.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
Indeed, one of the advantages

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
that the Americans will have

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
in terms of power in Asia

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
is all those countries

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
want an American insurance policy

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
against the rise of China.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
It's as though Mexico and Canada

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
were hostile neighbors to the United States,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
which they're not.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So these simple projections

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
of the Goldman Sachs type

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
are not telling us what we need to know

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:53.958
about power transition.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
But you might ask, well so what in any case?

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
Why does it matter? Who cares?

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Is this just a game

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that diplomats and academics play?

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
The answer is it matters quite a lot.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
Because, if you believe in decline

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and you get the answers wrong on this,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
the facts, not the myths,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
you may have policies which are very dangerous.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Let me give you an example from history.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
The Peloponnesian War

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
was the great conflict

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
in which the Greek city state system

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
tore itself apart

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
two and a half millennia ago.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
What caused it?

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Thucydides, the great historian of the the Peloponnesian War,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
said it was the rise in the power of Athens

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
and the fear it created in Sparta.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Notice both halves of that explanation.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Many people argue

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
that the 21st century

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
is going to repeat the 20th century,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
in which World War One,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
the great conflagration

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
in which the European state system

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
tore itself apart

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and destroyed its centrality in the world,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
that that was caused by

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
the rise in the power of Germany

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and the fear it created in Britain.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So there are people who are telling us

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
this is going to be reproduced today,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
that what we're going to see

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
is the same thing now in this century.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
No, I think that's wrong.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
It's bad history.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
For one thing, Germany had surpassed Britain

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
in industrial strength by 1900.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And as I said earlier,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
China has not passed the United States.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
But also, if you have this belief

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
and it creates a sense of fear,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
it leads to overreaction.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
And the greatest danger we have

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
of managing this power transition

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
of the shift toward the East is fear.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
To paraphrase Franklin Roosevelt

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
from a different context,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
the greatest thing we have to fear is fear itself.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
We don't have to fear the rise of China

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
or the return of Asia.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And if we have policies

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
in which we take it

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
in that larger historical perspective,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
we're going to be able

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
to manage this process.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
Let me say a word now

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
about the distribution of power

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
and how it relates to power diffusion

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and then pull these two types together.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
If you ask how is power distributed in the world today,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
it's distributed much like

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
a three-dimensional chess game.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
Top board:

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
military power among states.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
The United States is the only superpower,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
and it's likely to remain that way

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
for two or three decades.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
China's not going to replace the U.S. on this military board.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Middle board of this three-dimensional chess game:

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
economic power among states.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
Power is multi-polar.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
There are balancers --

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
the U.S., Europe,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
China, Japan

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
can balance each other.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
The bottom board of this three-dimensional,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
the board of transnational relations,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
things that cross borders outside the control of governments,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
things like climate change, drug trade,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
financial flows,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
pandemics,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
all these things that cross borders

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
outside the control of governments,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
there nobody's in charge.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
It makes no sense to call this unipolar

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
or multi-polar.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
Power is chaotically distributed.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And the only way you can solve these problems --

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
and this is where many greatest challenges

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
are coming in this century --

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
is through cooperation,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
through working together,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
which means that soft power becomes more important,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
that ability to organize networks

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
to deal with these kinds of problems

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and to be able to get cooperation.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
Another way of putting it

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
is that as we think of power in the 21st century,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
we want to get away from the idea

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
that power's always zero sum --

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
my gain is your loss and vice versa.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Power can also be positive sum,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
where your gain can be my gain.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
If China develops greater energy security

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
and greater capacity

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
to deal with its problems of carbon emissions,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
that's good for us

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
as well as good for China

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
as well as good for everybody else.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
So empowering China

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
to deal with its own problems of carbon

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
is good for everybody,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and it's not a zero sum, I win, you lose.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
It's one in which we can all gain.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
So as we think about power

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
in this century,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
we want to get away from this view

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
that it's all I win, you lose.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
Now I don't mean to be Pollyannaish about this.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Wars persist. Power persists.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
Military power is important.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
Keeping balances is important.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
All this still persists.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
Hard power is there,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and it will remain.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
But unless you learn how to mix

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
hard power with soft power

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
into strategies that I call smart power,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
you're not going to deal with the new kinds of problems

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
that we're facing.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
So the key question that we need to think about as we look at this

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
is how do we work together

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
to produce global public goods,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
things from which all of us can benefit?

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
How do we define our national interests

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
so that it's not just zero sum,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
but positive sum.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
In that sense, if we define our interests,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
for example, for the United States

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
the way Britain defined its interests in the 19th century,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
keeping an open trading system,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
keeping a monetary stability, keeping freedom of the seas --

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
those were good for Britain,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
they were good for others as well.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
And in the 21st century, you have to do an analog to that.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
How do we produce global public goods,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
which are good for us,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
but good for everyone at the same time?

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
And that's going to be the good news dimension

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
of what we need to think about

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
as we think of power in the 21st century.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
There are ways to define our interests

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
in which, while protecting ourselves with hard power,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
we can organize with others in networks

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
to produce, not only public goods,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
but ways that will enhance our soft power.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
So if one looks at the statements

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
that have been made about this,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
I am impressed that when Hillary Clinton

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
described the foreign policy

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
of the Obama administration,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
she said that the foreign policy of the Obama administration

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
was going to be smart power,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
as she put it, "using all the tools

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
in our foreign policy tool box."

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
And if we're going to deal

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
with these two great power shifts that I've described,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
the power shift represented by transition among states,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
the power shift represented

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
by diffusion of power away from all states,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
we're going to have to develop a new narrative of power

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
in which we combine hard and soft power

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
into strategies of smart power.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
And that's the good news I have. We can do that.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
Thank you very much.

title: Sustainable seafood? Let's get smart
transcript: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how I impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.So what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress. Restorative seafood allows for an evolving and dynamic system and acknowledges our relationship with the ocean as a resource, suggesting that we engage to replenish the ocean and to encourage its resiliency. It is a more hopeful, it is a more human, and is a more useful way of understanding our environment.Wallet guides — standard issue by lots in the marine conservation world — are very handy; they're a wonderful tool. Green, yellow and red lists [of] seafood species. The association is very easy: buy green, don't buy red, think twice about yellow. But in my mind, it's really not enough to just eat green list. We can't sustain this without the measure of our success really changing the fate of the species in the yellow and the red. But what if we eat only in the green list? You've got pole-caught yellowfin tuna here — comes from sustainable stocks. Pole caught — no bycatch. Great for fishermen. Lots of money. Supporting local economies. But it's a lion of the sea. It's a top predator.What's the context of this meal? Am I sitting down in a steakhouse to a 16-ounce portion of this? Do I do this three times a week? I might still be in the green list, but I'm not doing myself, or you, or the oceans any favors. The point is that we have to have a context, a gauge for our actions in all this. Example: I've heard that red wine is great for my health — antioxidants and minerals — heart healthy. That's great! I love red wine! I'm going to drink so much of it. I'm going to be so healthy. Well, how many bottles is it before you tell me that I have a problem? Well folks, we have a protein problem. We have lost this sensibility when it regards our food, and we are paying a cost. The problem is we are hiding that cost beneath the waves. We are hiding that cost behind the social acceptance of expanding waistlines. And we are hiding that cost behind monster profits.So the first thing about this idea of restorative seafood is that it really takes into account our needs. Restorative seafood might best be represented not by Jaws, or by Flipper, or the Gordon's fisherman, but rather, by the Jolly Green Giant. Vegetables: they might yet save the oceans. Sylvia likes to say that blue is the new green. Well I'd like to respectfully submit that broccoli green might then be the new blue. We must continue to eat the best seafood possible, if at all. But we also must eat it with a ton of vegetables. The best part about restorative seafood though is that it comes on the half-shell with a bottle of Tabasco and lemon wedges. It comes in a five-ounce portion of tilapia breaded with Dijon mustard and crispy, broiled breadcrumbs and a steaming pile of pecan quinoa pilaf with crunchy, grilled broccoli so soft and sweet and charred and smoky on the outside with just a hint of chili flake. Whooo! This is an easy sell. And the best part is all of those ingredients are available to every family at the neighborhood Walmart.Jamie Oliver is campaigning to save America from the way we eat. Sylvia is campaigning to save the oceans from the way we eat. There's a pattern here. Forget nuclear holocaust; it's the fork that we have to worry about. We have ravaged our Earth and then used the food that we've sourced to handicap ourselves in more ways than one. So I think we have this whole eating thing wrong. And so I think it's time we change what we expect from our food. Sustainability is complicated but dinner is a reality that we all very much understand. So let's start there.There's been a lot of movement recently in greening our food systems. Dan Barber and Alice Waters are leading passionately the green food Delicious Revolution. But green foods often represent a way for us to disregard the responsibility as eaters. Just because it comes from a green source doesn't mean we can treat it with disregard on the plate. We have eco-friendly shrimp. We can make them; we have that technology. But we can never have any eco-friendly all-you-can-eat shrimp buffet. It doesn't work. Heart-healthy dinner is a very important part of restorative seafood. While we try to manage declining marine populations, the media's recommending increased consumption of seafood. Studies say that tens of thousands of American grandmothers, grandfathers, mothers and fathers might be around for another birthday if we included more seafood. That's a reward I am not willing to pass up. But it's not all about the seafood. It's about the way that we look at our plates.As a chef, I realize the easiest thing for me to do is reduce the portion sizes on my plate. A couple things happened. I made more money. People started buying appetizers and salads, because they knew they weren't going to fill up on the entrees alone. People spent more time engaging in their meals, engaging with each other over their meals. People got, in short, more of what they came there for even though they got less protein. They got more calories over the course of a diversified meal. They got healthier. I made more money. This is great. Environmental consideration was served with every plate, but it was served with a heaping mound of consideration for human interests at the same time.One of the other things we did was begin to diversify the species that we served — small silverfish, anchovies, mackerel, sardines were uncommon. Shellfish, mussels, oysters, clams, tilapia, char — these were the common species. We were directing tastes towards more resilience, more restorative options. This is what we need to favor. This is what the green list says. But this is also how we can actually begin to restore our environment.But what of those big predators, those fashionable species, that green list tuna that I was talking about earlier? Well, if you must, I have a recipe for you. It pretty much works with any big fish in the ocean, so here we go. Start with a 16-ounce portion of big fish. Get a knife. Cut it into four portions. Put it on four plates. Mound up those four plates with vegetables and then open up the very best bottle of Burgundy you have, light the candles and celebrate it. Celebrate the opportunity you have to eat this. Invite your friends and neighbors over and repeat once a year, maybe.I expect a lot from food. I expect health and joy and family and community. I expect that producing ingredients, preparing dishes and eating meals is all part of the communion of human interests. I was lucky enough that my father was a fantastic cook. And he taught me very early on about the privilege that eating represents. I remember well the meals of my childhood. They were reasonable portions of protein served with copious quantities of vegetables and small amounts of starch, usually rice. This is still how I largely eat today. I get sick when I go to steakhouses. I get the meat sweats. It's like a hangover from protein. It's disgusting. But of all the dire news that you'll hear and that you have heard about the state of our oceans, I have the unfortunate burden of delivering to you possibly the very worst of it and that is this whole time your mother was right. Eat your vegetables. It's pretty straightforward.So what are we looking for in a meal? Well for health, I'm looking for wholesome ingredients that are good for my body. For joy, I'm looking for butter and salt and sexy things that make things taste less like penance. For family, I'm looking for recipes that genuflect to my own personal histories. For community though, we start at the very beginning. There's no escaping the fact that everything we eat has a global impact. So try and learn as best you can what that impact is and then take the first step to minimize it. We've seen an image of our blue planet, our world bank. But it is more than just a repository of our resources; it's also the global geography of the communion we call dinner. So if we all take only what we need, then we can begin to share the rest, we can begin to celebrate, we can begin to restore. We need to savor vegetables. We need to savor smaller portions of seafood. And we need to save dinner.Thank you.(Applause)

and joy and family and community.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
I expect that producing ingredients,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
preparing dishes and eating meals

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
is all part of the communion of human interests.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
I was lucky enough that my father was a fantastic cook.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And he taught me very early on

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
about the privilege that eating represents.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I remember well the meals of my childhood.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
They were reasonable portions of protein

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
served with copious quantities of vegetables

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
and small amounts of starch, usually rice.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
This is still how I largely eat today.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
I get sick when I go to steakhouses.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
I get the meat sweats.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
It's like a hangover from protein.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
It's disgusting.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
But of all the dire news that you'll hear

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and that you have heard about the state of our oceans,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
I have the unfortunate burden of delivering to you

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
possibly the very worst of it

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and that is this whole time

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
your mother was right.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
Eat your vegetables.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
It's pretty straightforward.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
So what are we looking for in a meal?

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Well for health, I'm looking for wholesome ingredients

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
that are good for my body.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
For joy, I'm looking for butter and salt

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
and sexy things that make things taste less like penance.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
For family, I'm looking for recipes

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
that genuflect to my own personal histories.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
For community though, we start at the very beginning.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
There's no escaping the fact

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that everything we eat has a global impact.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
So try and learn as best you can what that impact is

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and then take the first step to minimize it.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
We've seen an image of our blue planet,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
our world bank.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
But it is more than just a repository of our resources;

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
it's also the global geography

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
of the communion we call dinner.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
So if we all take only what we need,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
then we can begin to share the rest,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
we can begin to celebrate,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
we can begin to restore.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
We need to savor vegetables.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
We need to savor smaller portions of seafood.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And we need to save dinner.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Thank you.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
(Applause)
